<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Europe skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Europe</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-semi-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-semi-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-semi-indef</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Pp-move-indef&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Pp-move-indef (page does not exist)">Template:Pp-move-indef</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_Continent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox Continent (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox Continent</a>
</p><p><b>Europe</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Respell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Respell (page does not exist)">Template:Respell</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Respell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Respell (page does not exist)">Template:Respell</a><sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup>) is, by convention, one of the world's seven <a href="/w/index.php?title=Continent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Continent (page does not exist)">continents</a>. Comprising the westernmost <a href="/wiki/Peninsula" title="Peninsula">peninsula</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eurasia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eurasia (page does not exist)">Eurasia</a>, Europe is generally <a href="/w/index.php?title=Borders_of_the_continents&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Borders of the continents (page does not exist)">divided from Asia</a> by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Drainage_divide&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Drainage divide (page does not exist)">watershed divides</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Ural_Mountains" title="Ural Mountains">Ural</a> and <a href="/wiki/Caucasus_Mountains" title="Caucasus Mountains">Caucasus</a> Mountains, the <a href="/wiki/Ural_River" title="Ural River">Ural River</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Caspian_Sea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caspian Sea (page does not exist)">Caspian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black</a> Seas, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bosporus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bosporus (page does not exist)">waterways</a> connecting the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Sea" title="Aegean Sea">Aegean</a> Seas.<sup id="cite_ref-NatlGeoAtlas_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NatlGeoAtlas-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>Europe is bordered by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arctic_Ocean&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arctic Ocean (page does not exist)">Arctic Ocean</a> to the north, the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> to the west, the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> to the south, and the Black Sea and connected waterways to the southeast. Yet the borders of Europe—a concept dating back to <a href="/wiki/Classical_antiquity" title="Classical antiquity">classical antiquity</a>—are somewhat arbitrary, as the primarily <a href="/wiki/Physical_geography" title="Physical geography">physiographic</a> term "continent" can incorporate <a href="/wiki/Human_geography" title="Human geography">cultural and political</a> elements.
</p><p>Europe is the world's <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_continents&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of continents (page does not exist)">second-smallest</a> continent by surface area, covering about <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> or 2% of the Earth's surface and about 6.8% of its land area. Of Europe's approximately 50 countries, <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> is by far the largest by both area and population, taking up 40% of the continent (although the country has territory in both Europe and Asia), while <a href="/wiki/Vatican_City" title="Vatican City">Vatican City</a> is the smallest. Europe is the third-most populous continent after <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Africa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Africa (page does not exist)">Africa</a>, with a <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Europe" title="Demographics of Europe">population</a> of 733&#160;million or about 11% of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_population&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World population (page does not exist)">world's population</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p><p>Europe, in particular <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Ancient Greece</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Ancient Rome</a>, is the birthplace of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Western_culture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Western culture (page does not exist)">Western culture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> It played a predominant role in global affairs from the 15th century onwards, especially after the beginning of <a href="/wiki/Colonialism" title="Colonialism">colonialism</a>. Between the 16th and 20th centuries, European nations controlled at various times <a href="/wiki/European_colonisation_of_the_Americas" title="European colonisation of the Americas" class="mw-redirect">the Americas</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Colonisation_of_Africa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Colonisation of Africa (page does not exist)">most of Africa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">Oceania</a>, and large portions of Asia. The <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a>, which began in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Britain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Britain (page does not exist)">Great Britain</a> around the end of the 18th century, gave rise to radical economic, cultural, and social change in Western Europe, and eventually the wider world. Demographic growth meant that, by 1900, Europe's share of the world's population was 25%.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p><p>Both <a href="/wiki/World_war" title="World war">World Wars</a> were largely focused upon Europe, greatly contributing to a decline in <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western European</a> dominance in world affairs by the mid-20th century as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a> and <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> took prominence.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_534_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_534-6">[6]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>, Europe was divided along the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iron_Curtain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iron Curtain (page does not exist)">Iron Curtain</a> between <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> in the west and the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Pact" title="Warsaw Pact">Warsaw Pact</a> in the east. <a href="/wiki/European_integration" title="European integration">European integration</a> led to the formation of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> in Western Europe, both of which have been expanding eastward since the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Revolutions_of_1989&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Revolutions of 1989 (page does not exist)">revolutions of 1989</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union (page does not exist)">fall of the Soviet Union</a> in 1991.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Definition">Definition</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<center>
<div class="thumbinner"><div class="overflowbugx" style="overflow: auto;">
<p><small>Clickable map of Europe, showing one of the most commonly used <a href="/w/index.php?title=Boundaries_between_continents&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Boundaries between continents (page does not exist)">continental boundaries</a><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> <br /><b>Key:</b> <span style="color:blue"><b>blue</b></span>: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Transcontinental_country&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Transcontinental country (page does not exist)">states which straddle the border between Europe and Asia</a>;
<span style="color:green"><b>green</b></span>: states not geographically in Europe, but closely associated politically<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</small>
&lt;center&gt;
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Europe_and_Sea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Europe and Sea (page does not exist)">Template:Europe and Sea</a>
&lt;/center&gt;
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Herodotus_World_Map.jpg" title="File:Herodotus World Map.jpg">File:Herodotus World Map.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Reconstruction of <a href="/wiki/Herodotus" title="Herodotus">Herodotus</a>' world map</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:T_and_O_map_Guntherus_Ziner_1472.jpg" title="File:T and O map Guntherus Ziner 1472.jpg">File:T and O map Guntherus Ziner 1472.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A medieval <a href="/wiki/T_and_O_map" title="T and O map">T and O map</a> from 1472 showing the three continents as domains of the sons of <a href="/wiki/Noah" title="Noah">Noah</a> — Asia to Sem (<a href="/wiki/Shem" title="Shem">Shem</a>), Europe to Iafeth (<a href="/wiki/Japheth" title="Japheth">Japheth</a>), and Africa to Cham (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Ham,_son_of_Noah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ham, son of Noah (page does not exist)">Ham</a>)</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europe_As_A_Queen_Sebastian_Munster_1570.jpg" title="File:Europe As A Queen Sebastian Munster 1570.jpg">File:Europe As A Queen Sebastian Munster 1570.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Europa_regina&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Europa regina (page does not exist)">Europa regina</a></i> map from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cosmographia_(Sebastian_M%C3%BCnster)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cosmographia (Sebastian Münster) (page does not exist)">Münster (1570)</a>. The British Isles and Scandinavia are not included in Europe proper.</div></div></div>
<p>The use of the term "Europe" has developed gradually throughout history.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> In antiquity, the Greek historian <a href="/wiki/Herodotus" title="Herodotus">Herodotus</a> mentioned that the world had been divided by unknown persons into three parts, Europe, Asia, and Libya (Africa), with the <a href="/wiki/Nile" title="Nile">Nile</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Rioni_River" title="Rioni River">River Phasis</a> forming their boundaries—though he also states that some considered the <a href="/wiki/Don_River_(Russia)" title="Don River (Russia)">River Don</a>, rather than the Phasis, as the boundary between Europe and Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> Europe's eastern frontier was defined in the 1st century by geographer <a href="/wiki/Strabo" title="Strabo">Strabo</a> at the River Don.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Jubilees" title="Jubilees">Book of Jubilees</a></i> described the continents as the lands given by <a href="/wiki/Noah" title="Noah">Noah</a> to his three sons; Europe was defined as stretching from the <a href="/wiki/Pillars_of_Hercules" title="Pillars of Hercules">Pillars of Hercules</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Strait_of_Gibraltar" title="Strait of Gibraltar">Strait of Gibraltar</a>, separating it from <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">North Africa</a>, to the Don, separating it from <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>A cultural definition of Europe as the lands of <a href="/wiki/Christendom" title="Christendom">Latin Christendom</a> coalesced in the 8th century, signifying the new cultural condominium created through the confluence of Germanic traditions and Christian-Latin culture, defined partly in contrast with <a href="/wiki/Byzantium" title="Byzantium">Byzantium</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Islam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Islam (page does not exist)">Islam</a>, and limited to northern Iberia, the British Isles, France, Christianized western Germany, the Alpine regions and northern and central Italy.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> The concept is one of the lasting legacies of the <a href="/wiki/Carolingian_Renaissance" title="Carolingian Renaissance">Carolingian Renaissance</a>: "Europa" often figures in the letters of Charlemagne's court scholar, <a href="/wiki/Alcuin" title="Alcuin">Alcuin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> This division—as much cultural as geographical—was used until the <a href="/wiki/Late_Middle_Ages" title="Late Middle Ages">Late Middle Ages</a>, when it was challenged by the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery">Age of Discovery</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Why%3F&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Why? (page does not exist)">Template:Why?</a> The problem of redefining Europe was finally resolved in 1730 when, instead of waterways, the Swedish geographer and cartographer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philip_Johan_von_Strahlenberg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philip Johan von Strahlenberg (page does not exist)">von Strahlenberg</a> proposed the <a href="/wiki/Ural_Mountains" title="Ural Mountains">Ural Mountains</a> as the most significant eastern boundary, a suggestion that found favour in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tsardom_of_Russia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tsardom of Russia (page does not exist)">Russia</a> and throughout Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>Europe is now generally defined by geographers as the westernmost <a href="/wiki/Peninsula" title="Peninsula">peninsula</a> of Eurasia, with its boundaries marked by large bodies of water to the north, west and south; Europe's limits to the far east are usually taken to be the Urals, the <a href="/wiki/Ural_River" title="Ural River">Ural River</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Caspian_Sea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caspian Sea (page does not exist)">Caspian Sea</a>; to the southeast, including the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus_Mountains" title="Caucasus Mountains">Caucasus Mountains</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> and the waterways connecting the Black Sea to the Mediterranean Sea.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta-19">[19]</a></sup> Because of sociopolitical and cultural differences, there are various descriptions of Europe's boundary. For example, <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a> is approximate to <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia (or Asia Minor)</a>, but is usually considered part of Europe both culturally and politically and currently is a member state of the EU. In addition, <a href="/wiki/Malta" title="Malta">Malta</a> was considered an island of North Africa for centuries,<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a>, though nearer to <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">Greenland</a> (North America), is also generally included in Europe.
</p><p>Sometimes, the word 'Europe' is used in a geopolitically limiting way<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> to refer only to the European Union or, even more exclusively, a culturally defined core. On the other hand, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> has 47 member countries, and only 28 member states are in the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> In addition, people living in areas such as <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" title="Republic of Ireland">Ireland</a>, the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=North_Atlantic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="North Atlantic (page does not exist)">North Atlantic</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mediterranean&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mediterranean (page does not exist)">Mediterranean</a> islands and also in <a href="/wiki/Scandinavia" title="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a> may routinely refer to <a href="/wiki/Continental_Europe" title="Continental Europe">"continental" or "mainland" Europe</a> simply as Europe or "the Continent".<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europa_copy.jpg" title="File:Europa copy.jpg">File:Europa copy.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Europa and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bull_(mythology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bull (mythology) (page does not exist)">bull</a> on a Greek vase. Tarquinia Museum, circa 480 BC</div></div></div>
<p>In ancient <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greek_mythology&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greek mythology (page does not exist)">Greek mythology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Europa_(mythology)" title="Europa (mythology)">Europa</a> was a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Phoenicia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Phoenicia (page does not exist)">Phoenician</a> princess whom <a href="/wiki/Zeus" title="Zeus">Zeus</a> abducted after assuming the form of a dazzling white bull. He took her to the island of <a href="/wiki/Crete" title="Crete">Crete</a> where she gave birth to <a href="/wiki/Minos" title="Minos">Minos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rhadamanthus" title="Rhadamanthus">Rhadamanthus</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sarpedon" title="Sarpedon">Sarpedon</a>. For <a href="/wiki/Homer" title="Homer">Homer</a>, Europe (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Lang-grc&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Lang-grc (page does not exist)">Template:Lang-grc</a>, <i><span class="Unicode">Eurṓpē</span></i>; see also <a href="/wiki/List_of_Greek_place_names" title="List of Greek place names">List of Greek place names</a>) was a mythological queen of Crete, not a geographical designation.
</p><p>The etymology of <i>Europa</i> is uncertain.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> One theory suggests that it is derived from the <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a> εὐρύς (<i>eurus</i>), meaning "wide, broad"<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> and ὤψ/ὠπ-/ὀπτ- (<i>ōps</i>/<i>ōp</i>-/<i>opt-</i>), meaning "eye, face, countenance",<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> hence <i><span class="Unicode">Eurṓpē</span></i>, "wide-gazing", "broad of aspect" (compare with <a href="/wiki/Athena#Cult_and_attributes" title="Athena"><i>glauk<b>ōp</b>is</i> (γλαυκῶπις 'grey-eyed') Athena</a> or <a href="/wiki/Hera" title="Hera"><i>bo<b>ōp</b>is</i> (βοὠπις 'ox-eyed') Hera</a>). <i>Broad</i> has been an <a href="/wiki/Epithet" title="Epithet">epithet</a> of Earth itself in the reconstructed <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_religion" title="Proto-Indo-European religion">Proto-Indo-European religion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> Another theory suggests that it is based on a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Semitic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Semitic (page does not exist)">Semitic</a> word such as the <a href="/wiki/Akkadian_language" title="Akkadian language">Akkadian</a> <i>erebu</i> meaning "to go down, set" (cf. <a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Occident" class="extiw" title="wikt:Occident">Occident</a>),{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} <a href="/wiki/Cognate" title="Cognate">cognate</a> to Phoenician <i> 'ereb</i> "evening; west" and Arabic <a href="/wiki/Maghreb" title="Maghreb">Maghreb</a>, Hebrew <i>ma'ariv</i> (see also <i><a href="/wiki/Erebus" title="Erebus">Erebus</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_language" title="Proto-Indo-European language">PIE</a> <i>*h<sub>1</sub>regʷos</i>, "darkness"). However, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Martin_Litchfield_West&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Martin Litchfield West (page does not exist)">Martin Litchfield West</a> states that "phonologically, the match between Europa's name and any form of the Semitic word is very poor".<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>Whatever the origin of the name of the mythological figure, Εὐρώπη is first used as a geographical term in the 6th century BC, by Greek geographers such as <a href="/wiki/Anaximander" title="Anaximander">Anaximander</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hecataeus_of_Miletus" title="Hecataeus of Miletus">Hecataeus</a>. Anaximander placed the boundary between Asia and Europe along the <a href="/wiki/Phasis_River" title="Phasis River" class="mw-redirect">Phasis River</a> (the modern Rioni) in the Caucasus, a convention still followed by <a href="/wiki/Herodotus" title="Herodotus">Herodotus</a> in the 5th century BC.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> But the convention received by the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a> and surviving into modern usage is that of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_era" title="Roman era" class="mw-redirect">Roman era</a> used by Roman era authors such as <a href="/wiki/Posidonius" title="Posidonius">Posidonius</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Strabo" title="Strabo">Strabo</a><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Ptolemy" title="Ptolemy">Ptolemy</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup>
who took the <a href="/wiki/Tanais" title="Tanais">Tanais</a> (the modern Don River) as the boundary. 
The term "Europe" is first used for a cultural sphere in the <a href="/wiki/Carolingian_Renaissance" title="Carolingian Renaissance">Carolingian Renaissance</a> of the 9th century. From that time, the term designated the sphere of influence of the <a href="/wiki/Western_Church" title="Western Church" class="mw-redirect">Western Church</a>, as opposed to both the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" title="Eastern Orthodox" class="mw-redirect">Eastern Orthodox</a> churches and to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Islamic_world&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Islamic world (page does not exist)">Islamic world</a>. The modern convention, enlarging the area of "Europe" somewhat to the east and the southeast, develops in the 19th century.
</p><p>Most major world languages use words derived from "Europa" to refer to the "continent" (peninsula). Chinese, for example, uses the word <span class="Unicode"><i>Ōuzhōu</i></span> (歐洲); a similar Chinese-derived term <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nihongo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nihongo (page does not exist)">Template:Nihongo</a> is also sometimes used in Japanese such as in the Japanese name of the European Union, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nihongo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nihongo (page does not exist)">Template:Nihongo</a>, despite the <a href="/wiki/Katakana" title="Katakana">katakana</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Nihongo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Nihongo (page does not exist)">Template:Nihongo</a> being more commonly used. However, in some Turkic languages the originally Persian name <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Frangistan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frangistan (page does not exist)">Frangistan</a></i> (land of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Franks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Franks (page does not exist)">Franks</a>) is used casually in referring to much of Europe, besides official names such as <i>Avrupa</i> or <i>Evropa</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-davison_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-davison-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2012-09-24-Malta-Gozo_(Foto_Dietrich_Michael_Weidmann)_113.JPG" title="File:2012-09-24-Malta-Gozo (Foto Dietrich Michael Weidmann) 113.JPG">File:2012-09-24-Malta-Gozo (Foto Dietrich Michael Weidmann) 113.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/%C4%A0gantija" title="Ġgantija">Ġgantija</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malta_Island&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Malta Island (page does not exist)">Malta</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vinca_clay_figure_02.jpg" title="File:Vinca clay figure 02.jpg">File:Vinca clay figure 02.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lady_of_Vin%C4%8Da&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lady of Vinča (page does not exist)">Lady of Vinča</a></i>, neolithic pottery from <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">Serbia</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Stonehenge-Green.jpg" title="File:Stonehenge-Green.jpg">File:Stonehenge-Green.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Stonehenge" title="Stonehenge">Stonehenge</a>, <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Nebra_Scheibe.jpg" title="File:Nebra Scheibe.jpg">File:Nebra Scheibe.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Nebra_sky_disk" title="Nebra sky disk">Nebra sky disk</a> from <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a> <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a></div></div></div>
<p><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Homo_erectus_georgicus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Homo erectus georgicus (page does not exist)">Homo erectus georgicus</a></i>, which lived roughly 1.8&#160;million years ago in <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>, is the earliest <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hominid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hominid (page does not exist)">hominid</a> to have been discovered in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> Other hominid remains, dating back roughly 1&#160;million years, have been discovered in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Archaeological_Site_of_Atapuerca&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Archaeological Site of Atapuerca (page does not exist)">Atapuerca</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Neanderthal_man" title="Neanderthal man" class="mw-redirect">Neanderthal man</a> (named after the <a href="/wiki/Neandertal" title="Neandertal">Neandertal</a> valley in <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a>) appeared in Europe 150,000 years ago and disappeared from the fossil record about 28,000 BC, with this extinction probably <a href="/wiki/Neanderthal_extinction_hypotheses" title="Neanderthal extinction hypotheses">due to climate change</a>, and their final refuge being present-day <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a>. The Neanderthals were supplanted by modern humans (<a href="/wiki/Cro-Magnons" title="Cro-Magnons" class="mw-redirect">Cro-Magnons</a>), who appeared in Europe around 43 to 40 thousand years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_21_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_21-36">[36]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=European_Neolithic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="European Neolithic (page does not exist)">European Neolithic</a> period—marked by the cultivation of crops and the raising of livestock, increased numbers of settlements and the widespread use of pottery—began around 7000 BC in <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a>, probably influenced by earlier farming practices in <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Near_East" title="Near East">Near East</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Borza_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Borza-37">[37]</a></sup> It spread from the Balkans along the valleys of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Danube&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Danube (page does not exist)">Danube</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Rhine" title="Rhine">Rhine</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Linear_Pottery_culture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Linear Pottery culture (page does not exist)">Linear Pottery culture</a>) and along the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mediterranean_coast&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mediterranean coast (page does not exist)">Mediterranean coast</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Cardial_Ware&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cardial Ware (page does not exist)">Cardial culture</a>). Between 4500 and 3000 BC, these central European neolithic cultures developed further to the west and the north, transmitting newly acquired skills in producing copper artefacts. In Western Europe the Neolithic period was characterized not by large agricultural settlements but by field monuments, such as <a href="/wiki/Causewayed_enclosure" title="Causewayed enclosure">causewayed enclosures</a>, <a href="/wiki/Burial_mound" title="Burial mound" class="mw-redirect">burial mounds</a> and <a href="/wiki/Megalithic_tomb" title="Megalithic tomb" class="mw-redirect">megalithic tombs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Corded_Ware&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Corded Ware (page does not exist)">Corded Ware</a> cultural horizon flourished at the transition from the Neolithic to the <a href="/wiki/Chalcolithic" title="Chalcolithic">Chalcolithic</a>. During this period giant <a href="/wiki/Megalithic" title="Megalithic" class="mw-redirect">megalithic</a> monuments, such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Megalithic_Temples_of_Malta&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Megalithic Temples of Malta (page does not exist)">Megalithic Temples of Malta</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stonehenge" title="Stonehenge">Stonehenge</a>, were constructed throughout Western and Southern Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=European_Bronze_Age&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="European Bronze Age (page does not exist)">European Bronze Age</a> began circa 3200 BC in Greece.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=European_Iron_Age&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="European Iron Age (page does not exist)">European Iron Age</a> began around 1200 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> Iron Age colonisation by the <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greeks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Phoenicians" title="Phoenicians" class="mw-redirect">Phoenicians</a> gave rise to early <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mediterranean_basin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mediterranean basin (page does not exist)">Mediterranean</a> cities. Early <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iron_Age_Italy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iron Age Italy (page does not exist)">Iron Age Italy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Archaic_Greece" title="Archaic Greece">Greece</a> from around the 8th century BC gradually gave rise to historical Classical antiquity.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Classical_antiquity">Classical antiquity</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Veduta_di_Paestum_2010.jpg" title="File:Veduta di Paestum 2010.jpg">File:Veduta di Paestum 2010.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Greek Temple of Apollo, <a href="/wiki/Paestum" title="Paestum">Paestum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a></div></div></div>
<p>Ancient Greece had a profound influence on Western civilisation. Western <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democratic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Individualism" title="Individualism">individualistic culture</a> are often attributed to Ancient Greece.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_76_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_76-43">[43]</a></sup> The Greeks invented the <a href="/wiki/Polis" title="Polis">polis</a>, or city-state, which played a fundamental role in their concept of identity.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_82_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_82-44">[44]</a></sup> These Greek political ideals were rediscovered in the late 18th century by European philosophers and idealists. Greece also generated many cultural contributions: in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philosophy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philosophy (page does not exist)">philosophy</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Humanism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Humanism (page does not exist)">humanism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rationalism" title="Rationalism">rationalism</a> under <a href="/wiki/Aristotle" title="Aristotle">Aristotle</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Socrates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Socrates (page does not exist)">Socrates</a> and <a href="/wiki/Plato" title="Plato">Plato</a>; in <a href="/wiki/Historiography" title="Historiography">history</a> with <a href="/wiki/Herodotus" title="Herodotus">Herodotus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thucydides" title="Thucydides">Thucydides</a>; in dramatic and narrative verse, starting with the epic poems of <a href="/wiki/Homer" title="Homer">Homer</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_76_43-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_76-43">[43]</a></sup> in medicine with <a href="/wiki/Hippocrates" title="Hippocrates">Hippocrates</a> and <a href="/wiki/Galen" title="Galen">Galen</a>; and in science with <a href="/wiki/Pythagoras" title="Pythagoras">Pythagoras</a>, <a href="/wiki/Euclid" title="Euclid">Euclid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Archimedes" title="Archimedes">Archimedes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Heath_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Heath-45">[45]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Heath_Vol_2_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Heath_Vol_2-46">[46]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RomanEmpire_117.svg" title="File:RomanEmpire 117.svg">File:RomanEmpire 117.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> at its greatest extent</div></div></div>
<p>Another major influence came on Europe that would impact Western civilisation from the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> which left its mark on <a href="/wiki/Roman_law" title="Roman law">law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Politics" title="Politics">politics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">language</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_engineering&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roman engineering (page does not exist)">engineering</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roman architecture (page does not exist)">architecture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Centralized_government" title="Centralized government">government</a> and many more aspects in western civilization.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_77_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_77-48">[48]</a></sup> During the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Pax_romana&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pax romana (page does not exist)">pax romana</a></i>, the Roman Empire expanded to encompass the entire <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mediterranean_Basin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mediterranean Basin (page does not exist)">Mediterranean Basin</a> and much of Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-mieawl_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mieawl-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Stoicism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stoicism (page does not exist)">Stoicism</a> influenced <a href="/wiki/Roman_emperor" title="Roman emperor">Roman emperors</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Hadrian" title="Hadrian">Hadrian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Antoninus_Pius" title="Antoninus Pius">Antoninus Pius</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Marcus_Aurelius" title="Marcus Aurelius">Marcus Aurelius</a>, who all spent time on the Empire's northern border fighting <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Picts" title="Picts">Pictish</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scottish_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scottish people (page does not exist)">Scottish</a> tribes.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_123_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_123-50">[50]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> was eventually <a href="/wiki/Constantine_the_Great_and_Christianity" title="Constantine the Great and Christianity">legitimised</a> by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Constantine_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Constantine I (page does not exist)">Constantine I</a> after three centuries of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Persecution_of_early_Christians_in_the_Roman_Empire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Persecution of early Christians in the Roman Empire (page does not exist)">imperial persecution</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Middle_Ages">Early Middle Ages</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europe_around_650.jpg" title="File:Europe around 650.jpg">File:Europe around 650.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Europe ca. 650</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Partage_de_l%27Empire_carolingien_au_Trait%C3%A9_de_Verdun_en_843.JPG" title="File:Partage de l'Empire carolingien au Traité de Verdun en 843.JPG">File:Partage de l'Empire carolingien au Traité de Verdun en 843.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Carolingian_Empire" title="Carolingian Empire">Charlemagne's empire</a> at its greatest extent, 843</div></div></div>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/Decline_of_the_Roman_Empire" title="Decline of the Roman Empire">decline of the Roman Empire</a>, Europe entered a long period of change arising from what historians call the "<a href="/wiki/Age_of_Migrations" title="Age of Migrations" class="mw-redirect">Age of Migrations</a>". There were numerous invasions and migrations amongst the <a href="/wiki/Ostrogoths" title="Ostrogoths">Ostrogoths</a>, <a href="/wiki/Visigoths" title="Visigoths">Visigoths</a>, <a href="/wiki/Goths" title="Goths">Goths</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vandals" title="Vandals">Vandals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Huns" title="Huns">Huns</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Franks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Franks (page does not exist)">Franks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Angles" title="Angles">Angles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saxons" title="Saxons">Saxons</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slavs" title="Slavs">Slavs</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=European_Avars&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="European Avars (page does not exist)">Avars</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bulgars" title="Bulgars">Bulgars</a> and, later still, the <a href="/wiki/Vikings" title="Vikings">Vikings</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Magyars&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Magyars (page does not exist)">Magyars</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-mieawl_49-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mieawl-49">[49]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> thinkers such as <a href="/wiki/Petrarch" title="Petrarch">Petrarch</a> would later refer to this as the "Dark Ages".<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> Isolated monastic communities were the only places to safeguard and compile written knowledge accumulated previously; apart from this very few written records survive and much literature, philosophy, mathematics, and other thinking from the classical period disappeared from Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rolandfealty.jpg" title="File:Rolandfealty.jpg">File:Rolandfealty.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Roland" title="Roland">Roland</a> pledges <a href="/wiki/Fealty" title="Fealty">fealty</a> to <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne" title="Charlemagne">Charlemagne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Holy Roman Emperor">Holy Roman Emperor</a>.</div></div></div>From the 7th century, Byzantine history was greatly affected by the rise of Islam and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Caliphates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caliphates (page does not exist)">Caliphates</a>. Muslim <a href="/wiki/Arabs" title="Arabs" class="mw-redirect">Arabs</a> first invaded historically Roman territory under <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ab%C5%AB_Bakr&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Abū Bakr (page does not exist)">Abū Bakr</a>, first Caliph of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rashidun_Caliphate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rashidun Caliphate (page does not exist)">Rashidun Caliphate</a>, who entered <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_Syria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roman Syria (page does not exist)">Roman Syria</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_Mesopotamia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roman Mesopotamia (page does not exist)">Roman Mesopotamia</a>. Under <a href="/wiki/Umar" title="Umar">Umar</a>, the second Caliph, the Muslims decisively conquered Syria and Mesopotamia, as well as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_Palestine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roman Palestine (page does not exist)">Roman Palestine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roman_Egypt" title="Roman Egypt" class="mw-redirect">Roman Egypt</a>, and parts of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asia_Minor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asia Minor (page does not exist)">Asia Minor</a> and <a href="/wiki/Africa_(Roman_province)" title="Africa (Roman province)">Roman North Africa</a>. This trend continued under Umar's successors and under the <a href="/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate" title="Umayyad Caliphate">Umayyad Caliphate</a>, which conquered the rest of Mediterranean North Africa and most of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Visigothic_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Visigothic Kingdom (page does not exist)">Iberian Peninsula</a>. Over the next centuries Muslim forces were able to take further European territory, including <a href="/wiki/Cyprus_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="Cyprus in the Middle Ages">Cyprus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malta" title="Malta">Malta</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Emirate_of_Crete&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Emirate of Crete (page does not exist)">Crete</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Emirate_of_Sicily&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Emirate of Sicily (page does not exist)">Sicily</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_Islam_in_southern_Italy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of Islam in southern Italy (page does not exist)">parts of southern Italy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> In the East, <a href="/wiki/Volga_Bulgaria" title="Volga Bulgaria">Volga Bulgaria</a> became an Islamic state in the tenth century.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup>
<p>The Muslim conquest of Hispania began when the <a href="/wiki/Moors" title="Moors">Moors</a> (mostly <a href="/wiki/Berber_people" title="Berber people">Berbers</a> with some <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arab&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arab (page does not exist)">Arabs</a>) invaded the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christian (page does not exist)">Christian</a> <a href="/wiki/Visigoths" title="Visigoths">Visigothic</a> kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Iberian_peninsula" title="Iberian peninsula" class="mw-redirect">Iberia</a> in the year 711, under their Berber leader <a href="/wiki/Tariq_ibn_Ziyad" title="Tariq ibn Ziyad">Tariq ibn Ziyad</a>. They landed at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gibraltar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gibraltar (page does not exist)">Gibraltar</a> on 30 April and worked their way northward. Tariq's forces were joined the next year by those of his superior, <a href="/wiki/Musa_ibn_Nusair" title="Musa ibn Nusair" class="mw-redirect">Musa ibn Nusair</a>. During the eight-year campaign most of the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a> was brought under <a href="/wiki/Muslim" title="Muslim">Muslim</a> rule — save for small areas in the northwest (<a href="/wiki/Asturias" title="Asturias">Asturias</a>) and largely <a href="/wiki/Basque_people" title="Basque people">Basque</a> regions in the <a href="/wiki/Pyrenees" title="Pyrenees">Pyrenees</a>, with the exception of the Basque <a href="/wiki/Banu_Qasi" title="Banu Qasi">Banu Qasi</a> Muslim dynasty. This territory, under the Arabic name <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">Al-Andalus</a>, became part of the expanding <a href="/w/index.php?title=Umayyad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Umayyad (page does not exist)">Umayyad</a> empire.
</p><p>The unsuccessful <a href="/w/index.php?title=Siege_of_Constantinople_(717%E2%80%93718)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Siege of Constantinople (717–718) (page does not exist)">second siege of Constantinople</a> (717) weakened the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Umayyad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Umayyad (page does not exist)">Umayyad dynasty</a> and reduced their prestige. After their success in overrunning Iberia, the conquerors moved northeast across the Pyrenees, but were defeated by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Frankish_Empire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Frankish Empire (page does not exist)">Frankish</a> leader <a href="/wiki/Charles_Martel" title="Charles Martel">Charles Martel</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Tours" title="Battle of Tours">Battle of Poitiers</a> in 732, though they continued to raid and capture cities as far as <a href="/wiki/Avignon" title="Avignon">Avignon</a>. The Umayyads were overthrown in 750 by the '<a href="/w/index.php?title=Abb%C4%81sids&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Abbāsids (page does not exist)">Abbāsids</a> and most of the Umayyad clan massacred.
</p><p>A surviving Umayyad prince, <a href="/wiki/Abd_al-Rahman_I" title="Abd al-Rahman I">Abd al-Rahman I</a>, escaped to Iberia and founded a new Umayyad dynasty in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Caliph_of_Cordoba&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caliph of Cordoba (page does not exist)">Emirate of Cordoba</a>, (756). Charles Martel's son, <a href="/wiki/Pippin_the_Short" title="Pippin the Short" class="mw-redirect">Pippin the Short</a> retook <a href="/wiki/Narbonne" title="Narbonne">Narbonne</a>, and his grandson Charlemagne established the <a href="/wiki/Marca_Hispanica" title="Marca Hispanica">Marca Hispanica</a> across the Pyrenees in part of what today is <a href="/wiki/Catalonia" title="Catalonia">Catalonia</a>, reconquering <a href="/wiki/Girona" title="Girona">Girona</a> in 785 and <a href="/wiki/Barcelona" title="Barcelona">Barcelona</a> in 801. The Umayyads in Iberia proclaimed themselves caliphs in 929.
</p><p>During the Dark Ages, the <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">Western Roman Empire</a> fell under the control of various tribes. The Germanic and Slav tribes established their domains over Western and Eastern Europe respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_143_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_143-56">[56]</a></sup> Eventually the Frankish tribes were united under <a href="/wiki/Clovis_I" title="Clovis I">Clovis&#160;I</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_162_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_162-57">[57]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Charlemagne" title="Charlemagne">Charlemagne</a>, a Frankish king of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carolingian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carolingian (page does not exist)">Carolingian</a> dynasty who had conquered most of Western Europe, was anointed "<a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Holy Roman Emperor">Holy Roman Emperor</a>" by the Pope in 800. This led in 962 to the founding of the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Roman_Empire" title="Holy Roman Empire">Holy Roman Empire</a>, which eventually became centred in the German principalities of central Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_166_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_166-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 9th century emerged in Central Europe powerful <a href="/wiki/Great_Moravia" title="Great Moravia">Great Moravia</a>, it was the first West Slavic state. Moravia reached its largest territorial extent under <a href="/wiki/Svatopluk_I_of_Moravia" title="Svatopluk I of Moravia">Svatopluk I</a> and caused a series of armed conflicts with East Francia.
</p><p>The predominantly <a href="/w/index.php?title=Medieval_Greek&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Medieval Greek (page does not exist)">Greek speaking</a> <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Roman_Empire" title="Eastern Roman Empire" class="mw-redirect">Eastern Roman Empire</a> became known in the West as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Byzantine_Empire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Byzantine Empire (page does not exist)">Byzantine Empire</a>. Its capital was <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a>. Emperor <a href="/wiki/Justinian_I" title="Justinian I">Justinian I</a> presided over Constantinople's first golden age: he established a <a href="/wiki/Code_of_Justinian" title="Code of Justinian" class="mw-redirect">legal code</a>, funded the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Hagia_Sophia" title="Hagia Sophia">Hagia Sophia</a> and brought the Christian church under state control.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_135_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_135-59">[59]</a></sup> Fatally weakened by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Siege_of_Constantinople_(1204)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Siege of Constantinople (1204) (page does not exist)">sack of Constantinople in 1204</a>, during the <a href="/wiki/Fourth_Crusade" title="Fourth Crusade">Fourth Crusade</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-DuikerSpielvogel2010_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DuikerSpielvogel2010-60">[60]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Findlay2006_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Findlay2006-61">[61]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Browning1992_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Browning1992-62">[62]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Byfield2008_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Byfield2008-63">[63]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Golna2004_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Golna2004-64">[64]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Powell2001_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Powell2001-65">[65]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Irvin2002_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Irvin2002-66">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Frucht2004_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Frucht2004-67">[67]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DuikerSpielvogel2010v2_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DuikerSpielvogel2010v2-68">[68]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Byzantine_Empire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Byzantine Empire (page does not exist)">Byzantium</a> <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">fell in 1453</a> when it was conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_211_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_211-69">[69]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Peters2006_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Peters2006-70">[70]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Chronicles_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Chronicles-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages">Middle Ages</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The economic growth of Europe around the year 1000, together with the lack of safety on the mainland trading routes, made possible the development of major commercial routes along the coast of the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>. In this context, the growing independence acquired by some coastal cities gave the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maritime_Republics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maritime Republics (page does not exist)">Maritime Republics</a> a leading role in the European scene.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Philip_II_and_Tancred_meeting_in_Messina_-_British_Library_Royal_MS_16_G_vi_f350r_(detail).jpg" title="File:Philip II and Tancred meeting in Messina - British Library Royal MS 16 G vi f350r (detail).jpg">File:Philip II and Tancred meeting in Messina - British Library Royal MS 16 G vi f350r (detail).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tancred_of_Sicily&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tancred of Sicily (page does not exist)">Tancred of Sicily</a> and <a href="/wiki/Philip_II_of_France" title="Philip II of France">Philip II of France</a>, during the <a href="/wiki/Third_Crusade" title="Third Crusade">Third Crusade</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Middle Ages on the mainland were dominated by the two upper echelons of the social structure: the nobility and the clergy. <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">Feudalism</a> developed in <a href="/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="France (page does not exist)">France</a> in the Early Middle Ages and soon spread throughout Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_158_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_158-72">[72]</a></sup> A struggle for influence between the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nobility&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nobility (page does not exist)">nobility</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Monarchy" title="Monarchy">monarchy</a> in England led to the writing of the <a href="/wiki/Magna_Carta" title="Magna Carta">Magna Carta</a> and the establishment of a <a href="/wiki/Parliament" title="Parliament">parliament</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_186_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_186-73">[73]</a></sup> The primary source of culture in this period came from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_Catholic_Church&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roman Catholic Church (page does not exist)">Roman Catholic Church</a>. Through monasteries and cathedral schools, the Church was responsible for education in much of Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_158_72-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_158-72">[72]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Papacy" title="Papacy" class="mw-redirect">Papacy</a> reached the height of its power during the High Middle Ages. An <a href="/w/index.php?title=East-West_Schism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East-West Schism (page does not exist)">East-West Schism</a> in 1054 split the former Roman Empire religiously, with the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a> in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Byzantine_Empire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Byzantine Empire (page does not exist)">Byzantine Empire</a> and the Roman Catholic Church in the former Western Roman Empire. In 1095 <a href="/wiki/Pope_Urban_II" title="Pope Urban II">Pope Urban II</a> called for a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crusades&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crusades (page does not exist)">crusade</a> against <a href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims" class="mw-redirect">Muslims</a> occupying <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Holy_Land" title="Holy Land">Holy Land</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_192_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_192-74">[74]</a></sup> In Europe itself, the Church organised the <a href="/wiki/Inquisition" title="Inquisition">Inquisition</a> against heretics. In <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Reconquista" title="Reconquista">Reconquista</a> concluded with the fall of <a href="/wiki/Granada" title="Granada">Granada</a> in 1492, ending over seven centuries of Islamic rule in the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_199_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_199-75">[75]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mongols_suzdal.jpg" title="File:Mongols suzdal.jpg">File:Mongols suzdal.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The sacking of <a href="/wiki/Suzdal" title="Suzdal">Suzdal</a> by <a href="/wiki/Batu_Khan" title="Batu Khan">Batu Khan</a> in 1238, during the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Europe" title="Mongol invasion of Europe">Mongol invasion of Europe</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>In the 11th and 12th centuries, constant incursions by nomadic <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">Turkic</a> tribes, such as the <a href="/wiki/Pechenegs" title="Pechenegs">Pechenegs</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cuman-Kipchak_Confederation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cuman-Kipchak Confederation (page does not exist)">Cuman-Kipchaks</a>, caused a massive migration of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slavic_peoples&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Slavic peoples (page does not exist)">Slavic</a> populations to the safer, heavily forested regions of the north and temporarily halted the expansion of the Rus' state to the south and east.<sup id="cite_ref-Klyuch1_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Klyuch1-76">[76]</a></sup> Like many other parts of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eurasia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eurasia (page does not exist)">Eurasia</a>, these territories were <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mongol_invasion_of_Rus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mongol invasion of Rus (page does not exist)">overrun by the Mongols</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> The invaders, who became known as <a href="/wiki/Tatars" title="Tatars">Tatars</a>, were mostly Turkic under Mongol command. They established the state of the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horde" title="Golden Horde">Golden Horde</a>, which later adopted Islam as a religion and ruled over modern-day southern and central Russia for more than three centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Famine_of_1315%E2%80%931317&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Famine of 1315–1317 (page does not exist)">Great Famine of 1315–1317</a> was the first <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crisis_of_the_Late_Middle_Ages&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crisis of the Late Middle Ages (page does not exist)">crisis</a> that would strike Europe in the late Middle Ages.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> The period between 1348 and 1420 witnessed the heaviest loss. The population of <a href="/wiki/France_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="France in the Middle Ages">France</a> was reduced by half.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> Medieval Britain was afflicted by 95 famines,<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> and France suffered the effects of 75 or more in the same period.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> Europe was devastated in the mid-14th century by the <a href="/wiki/Black_Death" title="Black Death">Black Death</a>, one of the most deadly <a href="/wiki/Pandemic" title="Pandemic">pandemics</a> in human history which killed an estimated 25&#160;million people in Europe alone—a third of the <a href="/wiki/Medieval_demography" title="Medieval demography">European population</a> at the time.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>The plague had a devastating effect on Europe's social structure; it induced people to live for the moment as illustrated by <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Boccaccio" title="Giovanni Boccaccio">Giovanni Boccaccio</a> in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Decameron&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Decameron (page does not exist)">The Decameron</a></i> (1353). It was a serious blow to the Roman Catholic Church and led to increased <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Jews" title="Persecution of Jews">persecution of Jews</a>, foreigners, <a href="/wiki/Beggars" title="Beggars" class="mw-redirect">beggars</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leper" title="Leper" class="mw-redirect">lepers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_223_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_223-86">[86]</a></sup> The plague is thought to have returned every generation with varying <a href="/wiki/Virulence" title="Virulence">virulence</a> and mortalities until the 18th century.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> During this period, more than 100 plague <a href="/wiki/List_of_epidemics" title="List of epidemics">epidemics</a> swept across Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-Revill_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Revill-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_modern_period">Early modern period</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Raffael_058.jpg" title="File:Raffael 058.jpg">File:Raffael 058.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/School_of_Athens" title="School of Athens" class="mw-redirect">The School of Athens</a> by <a href="/wiki/Raphael" title="Raphael">Raphael</a>: Contemporaries such as <a href="/wiki/Michelangelo" title="Michelangelo">Michelangelo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">Leonardo da Vinci</a> (centre) are portrayed as classical scholars</div></div></div>
<p>The Renaissance was a period of cultural change originating in <a href="/wiki/Florence" title="Florence">Florence</a> and later spreading to the rest of Europe. in the 14th century. The rise of a <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_humanism" title="Renaissance humanism">new humanism</a> was accompanied by the recovery of forgotten <a href="/w/index.php?title=Classical_Greece&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Classical Greece (page does not exist)">classical Greek</a> and Arabic knowledge from <a href="/wiki/Monasticism" title="Monasticism">monastic</a> libraries, often re-translated from Arabic into <a href="/wiki/Latin_language" title="Latin language" class="mw-redirect">Latin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Barrett_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barrett-89">[89]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> The Renaissance spread across Europe between the 14th and 16th centuries: it saw the flowering of <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_art" title="Renaissance art">art</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philosophy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philosophy (page does not exist)">philosophy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music" title="Music">music</a>, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_science_in_the_Renaissance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of science in the Renaissance (page does not exist)">sciences</a>, under the joint patronage of <a href="/wiki/Royal_family" title="Royal family">royalty</a>, the nobility, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_Catholic_Church&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roman Catholic Church (page does not exist)">Roman Catholic Church</a>, and an emerging merchant class.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_254_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_254-92">[92]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup> Patrons in Italy, including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Medici&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Medici (page does not exist)">Medici</a> family of Florentine bankers and the <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Popes</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a>, funded prolific <a href="/wiki/Quattrocento" title="Quattrocento">quattrocento</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cinquecento&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cinquecento (page does not exist)">cinquecento</a> artists such as <a href="/wiki/Raphael" title="Raphael">Raphael</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michelangelo" title="Michelangelo">Michelangelo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci" title="Leonardo da Vinci">Leonardo da Vinci</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_292_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_292-95">[95]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>Political intrigue within the Church in the mid-14th century caused the <a href="/wiki/Western_Schism" title="Western Schism">Great Schism</a>. During this forty-year period, two popes—one in <a href="/wiki/Avignon" title="Avignon">Avignon</a> and one in Rome—claimed rulership over the Church. Although the schism was eventually healed in 1417, the papacy's spiritual authority had suffered greatly.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_193_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_193-97">[97]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Martin_Luther_by_Lucas_Cranach_der_%C3%84ltere.jpeg" title="File:Martin Luther by Lucas Cranach der Ältere.jpeg">File:Martin Luther by Lucas Cranach der Ältere.jpeg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Martin_Luther&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Martin Luther (page does not exist)">Martin Luther</a> initiated the <a href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" title="Protestant Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Church's power was further weakened by the Protestant Reformation (1517–1648), initially sparked <a href="/wiki/The_Ninety-Five_Theses" title="The Ninety-Five Theses">by the works of</a> German theologian <a href="/w/index.php?title=Martin_Luther&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Martin Luther (page does not exist)">Martin Luther</a>, a result of the lack of reform within the Church. The Reformation also damaged the Holy Roman Empire's power, as German princes became divided between <a href="/wiki/Protestant" title="Protestant" class="mw-redirect">Protestant</a> and Roman Catholic faiths.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_256_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_256-98">[98]</a></sup> This eventually led to the <a href="/wiki/Thirty_Years_War" title="Thirty Years War" class="mw-redirect">Thirty Years War</a> (1618–1648), which crippled the Holy Roman Empire and devastated much of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Early_Modern_history_of_Germany&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Early Modern history of Germany (page does not exist)">Germany</a>, killing between 25 and 40 percent of its population.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> In the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/Peace_of_Westphalia" title="Peace of Westphalia">Peace of Westphalia</a>, France rose to predominance within Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_269_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_269-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 17th century in southern and eastern Europe was a period of general <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_General_Crisis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The General Crisis (page does not exist)">decline</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> Eastern Europe experienced more than 150 famines in a 200-year period between 1501 to 1700.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> In the 15th–18th centuries, when the disintegrating khanates of the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horde" title="Golden Horde">Golden Horde</a> were conquered by Russia, <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Tatars" title="Crimean Tatars">Tatars</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Khanate" title="Crimean Khanate">Crimean Khanate</a> frequently <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crimean-Nogai_raids_into_East_Slavic_lands&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crimean-Nogai raids into East Slavic lands (page does not exist)">raided</a> Eastern Slavic lands to capture slaves.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Vienna" title="Battle of Vienna">Battle of Vienna</a> in 1683 broke the advance of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Turks</a> into Europe, and marked the political hegemony of the <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_dynasty" title="Habsburg dynasty" class="mw-redirect">Habsburg dynasty</a> in central Europe.
</p><p>The Renaissance and the <a href="/wiki/New_Monarchs" title="New Monarchs">New Monarchs</a> marked the start of an Age of Discovery, a period of exploration, invention, and scientific development.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> Among the great figures of the Western <a href="/wiki/Scientific_revolution" title="Scientific revolution">scientific revolution</a> of the 16th and 17th centuries were <a href="/wiki/Copernicus" title="Copernicus" class="mw-redirect">Copernicus</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kepler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kepler (page does not exist)">Kepler</a>, <a href="/wiki/Galileo" title="Galileo" class="mw-redirect">Galileo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Newton" title="Isaac Newton">Isaac Newton</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup> According to Peter Barrett, "It is widely accepted that 'modern science' arose in the Europe of the 17th century (towards the end of the Renaissance), introducing a new understanding of the natural world."<sup id="cite_ref-Barrett_89-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barrett-89">[89]</a></sup> In the 15th century, <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portugal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a>, two of the greatest naval powers of the time, took the lead in exploring the world.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_296_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_296-107">[107]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">Christopher Columbus</a> reached the <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_World&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New World (page does not exist)">New World</a> in 1492, and soon after the Spanish and Portuguese began establishing colonial empires in the Americas.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_338_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_338-108">[108]</a></sup> France, the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> and <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a> soon followed in building large colonial empires with vast holdings in Africa, <a href="/wiki/The_Americas" title="The Americas" class="mw-redirect">the Americas</a>, and Asia.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="18th_and_19th_centuries">18th and 19th centuries</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Napoleons_retreat_from_moscow.jpg" title="File:Napoleons retreat from moscow.jpg">File:Napoleons retreat from moscow.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon</a>'s retreat from Russia in 1812. Napoleon's <i><a href="/wiki/Grande_Arm%C3%A9e" title="Grande Armée">Grande Armée</a></i> had lost about half a million men.</div></div></div>
