<p>The Age of Enlightenment was a powerful intellectual movement during the 18th century promoting scientific and reason-based thoughts.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_255_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_255-111">[111]</a></sup> Discontent with the aristocracy and clergy's monopoly on political power in France resulted in the French Revolution and the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/French_First_Republic" title="French First Republic">First Republic</a> as a result of which the monarchy and many of the nobility perished during the initial <a href="/wiki/Reign_of_Terror" title="Reign of Terror">reign of terror</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon Bonaparte</a> rose to power in the aftermath of the French Revolution and established the <a href="/w/index.php?title=First_French_Empire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="First French Empire (page does not exist)">First French Empire</a> that, during the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>, grew to encompass large parts of Europe before collapsing in 1815 with the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Waterloo" title="Battle of Waterloo">Battle of Waterloo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_360_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_360-113">[113]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Empire" title="Napoleonic Empire" class="mw-redirect">Napoleonic rule</a> resulted in the further dissemination of the ideals of the French Revolution, including that of the <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">nation-state</a>, as well as the widespread adoption of the French models of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Centralised_government&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Centralised government (page does not exist)">administration</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Napoleonic_code&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Napoleonic code (page does not exist)">law</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Education_in_France" title="Education in France">education</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_350_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_350-117">[117]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna" title="Congress of Vienna">Congress of Vienna</a>, convened after Napoleon's downfall, established a new <a href="/w/index.php?title=Balance_of_power_(international_relations)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Balance of power (international relations) (page does not exist)">balance of power</a> in Europe centred on the five "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Power&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Power (page does not exist)">Great Powers</a>": the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="France (page does not exist)">France</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prussia" title="Prussia">Prussia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Austrian_Empire" title="Austrian Empire">Habsburg Austria</a>, and Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_367_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_367-118">[118]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Marshall%27s_flax-mill,_Holbeck,_Leeds_-_interior_-_c.1800.jpg" title="File:Marshall's flax-mill, Holbeck, Leeds - interior - c.1800.jpg">File:Marshall's flax-mill, Holbeck, Leeds - interior - c.1800.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Marshall's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Temple_Works&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Temple Works (page does not exist)">Temple Works</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> started in <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain" title="Kingdom of Great Britain">Great Britain</a></div></div></div>
<p>This balance would remain in place until the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Revolutions_of_1848&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Revolutions of 1848 (page does not exist)">Revolutions of 1848</a>, during which liberal uprisings affected all of Europe except for Russia and the United Kingdom. These revolutions were eventually put down by conservative elements and few reforms resulted.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_371_119-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_371-119">[119]</a></sup> In 1867, the <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_empire" title="Austro-Hungarian empire" class="mw-redirect">Austro-Hungarian empire</a> was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ausgleich&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ausgleich (page does not exist)">formed</a>; and 1871 saw the unifications of both <a href="/wiki/Italian_unification" title="Italian unification">Italy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Unification_of_Germany" title="Unification of Germany">Germany</a> as <a href="/wiki/Nation-states" title="Nation-states" class="mw-redirect">nation-states</a> from smaller principalities.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> Likewise, in 1878 the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Berlin" title="Congress of Berlin">Congress of Berlin</a> has conveyed formal recognition to the <i>de facto</i> independent principalities of <a href="/wiki/Montenegro" title="Montenegro">Montenegro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">Serbia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> started in <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain" title="Kingdom of Great Britain">Great Britain</a> in the last part of the 18th century and spread throughout Europe. The invention and implementation of new technologies resulted in rapid urban growth, mass employment, and the rise of a new working class.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> Reforms in social and economic spheres followed, including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Factory_Acts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Factory Acts (page does not exist)">first laws</a> on <a href="/wiki/Child_labour" title="Child labour">child labour</a>, the legalisation of <a href="/wiki/Trade_union" title="Trade union">trade unions</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Abolitionism_in_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Abolitionism in the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">abolition of slavery</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> In Britain, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Public_Health_Act_1875&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Public Health Act 1875 (page does not exist)">Public Health Act 1875</a> was passed, which significantly improved living conditions in many British cities.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> Europe's population increased from about 100 million in 1700 to 400 million by 1900.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> The last major famine recorded in Western Europe, the <a href="/wiki/Great_Famine_(Ireland)" title="Great Famine (Ireland)">Irish Potato Famine</a>, caused death and mass emigration of millions of Irish people.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> In the 19th century, 70&#160;million people left Europe in migrations to various European colonies abroad and to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="20th_century_to_the_present">20th century to the present</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_Europe_alliances_1914-en.svg" title="File:Map Europe alliances 1914-en.svg">File:Map Europe alliances 1914-en.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">European military alliances just prior to the start of WWI</div></div></div>
<p>Two World Wars and an economic depression dominated the first half of the 20th century. World War I was fought between 1914 and 1918. It started when <a href="/w/index.php?title=Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand_of_Austria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria (page does not exist)">Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria</a> was assassinated by the <a href="/wiki/Serbs_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Serbs of Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnian Serb</a> <a href="/wiki/Gavrilo_Princip" title="Gavrilo Princip">Gavrilo Princip</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_407_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_407-128">[128]</a></sup> Most European nations were drawn into the war, which was fought between the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Entente_Powers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Entente Powers (page does not exist)">Entente Powers</a> (<a href="/wiki/French_Third_Republic" title="French Third Republic">France</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">Belgium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">Serbia</a>, Portugal, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Russian_Empire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Russian Empire (page does not exist)">Russia</a>, the United Kingdom, and later <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a>, and the United States) and the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a> (<a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>, <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">Germany</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>). The War left more than 16&#160;million civilians and military dead.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_440_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_440-129">[129]</a></sup> Over 60&#160;million European soldiers were mobilised from 1914 to 1918.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bundesarchiv_Bild_183-H25224,_Guernica,_Ruinen.jpg" title="File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-H25224, Guernica, Ruinen.jpg">File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-H25224, Guernica, Ruinen.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Ruins of <a href="/wiki/Guernica" title="Guernica">Guernica</a> (1937). The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_Civil_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spanish Civil War (page does not exist)">Spanish Civil War</a> claimed the lives of over 500,000 people.</div></div></div>
<p>Partly as a result of its defeat Russia was plunged into the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a>, which threw down the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Russian_Empire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Russian Empire (page does not exist)">Tsarist monarchy</a> and replaced it with the <a href="/wiki/Communist" title="Communist" class="mw-redirect">communist</a> <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_480_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_480-131">[131]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a> and the Ottoman Empire collapsed and broke up into separate nations, and many other nations had their borders redrawn. The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Treaty of Versailles">Treaty of Versailles</a>, which officially ended World War I in 1919, was harsh towards Germany, upon whom it placed full responsibility for the war and imposed heavy sanctions.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_443_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_443-132">[132]</a></sup>
</p><p>Excess deaths in Russia over the course of World War I and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a> (including the postwar <a href="/w/index.php?title=Russian_famine_of_1921&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Russian famine of 1921 (page does not exist)">famine</a>) amounted to a combined total of 18 million.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> In 1932–1933, under <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stalin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stalin (page does not exist)">Stalin</a>'s leadership, confiscations of grain by the Soviet authorities contributed to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soviet_famine_of_1932-1933&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soviet famine of 1932-1933 (page does not exist)">second Soviet famine</a> which caused millions of deaths;<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> surviving <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kulak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kulak (page does not exist)">kulaks</a> were persecuted and many sent to <a href="/wiki/Gulag" title="Gulag">Gulags</a> to do <a href="/wiki/Unfree_labour" title="Unfree labour">forced labour</a>. Stalin was also responsible for the <a href="/wiki/Great_Purge" title="Great Purge">Great Purge</a> of 1937–38 in which the <a href="/wiki/NKVD" title="NKVD">NKVD</a> executed 681,692 people;<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> millions of people were <a href="/wiki/Population_transfer_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Population transfer in the Soviet Union">deported and exiled</a> to remote areas of the Soviet Union.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup>
</p><p>Economic instability, caused in part by debts incurred in the First World War and 'loans' to Germany played havoc in Europe in the late 1920s and 1930s. This and the <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street_Crash_of_1929" title="Wall Street Crash of 1929">Wall Street Crash of 1929</a> brought about the worldwide Great Depression. Helped by the economic crisis, social instability and the threat of communism, <a href="/wiki/Fascism" title="Fascism">fascist movements</a> developed throughout Europe placing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adolf_Hitler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adolf Hitler (page does not exist)">Adolf Hitler</a> of <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>, <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Franco" title="Francisco Franco">Francisco Franco</a> of Spain and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Benito_Mussolini&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Benito Mussolini (page does not exist)">Benito Mussolini</a> of Italy in power.<sup id="cite_ref-hobsbawn_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hobsbawn-137">[137]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_438_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_438-138">[138]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1933, Hitler became the leader of Germany and began to work towards his goal of building Greater Germany. Germany re-expanded and took back the <a href="/wiki/Saarland" title="Saarland">Saarland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rhineland" title="Rhineland">Rhineland</a> in 1935 and 1936. In 1938, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Austria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Austria (page does not exist)">Austria</a> became a part of Germany following the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Anschluss&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Anschluss (page does not exist)">Anschluss</a>. Later that year, following the <a href="/wiki/Munich_Agreement" title="Munich Agreement">Munich Agreement</a> signed by Germany, France, the United Kingdom and Italy, Germany annexed the <a href="/wiki/Sudetenland" title="Sudetenland">Sudetenland</a>, which was a part of <a href="/wiki/Czechoslovakia" title="Czechoslovakia">Czechoslovakia</a> inhabited by ethnic Germans, and in early 1939, the remainder of Czechoslovakia was split into the <a href="/wiki/Protectorate_of_Bohemia_and_Moravia" title="Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia">Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia</a>, controlled by Germany, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Slovak_Republic_(1939%E2%80%931945)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Slovak Republic (1939–1945) (page does not exist)">Slovak Republic</a>. At the time, Britain and France preferred a policy of <a href="/wiki/Appeasement" title="Appeasement">appeasement</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hamburg_after_the_1943_bombing.jpg" title="File:Hamburg after the 1943 bombing.jpg">File:Hamburg after the 1943 bombing.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Burned-out buildings in <a href="/wiki/Hamburg" title="Hamburg">Hamburg</a>, 1944 or 45</div></div></div>
<p>With tensions mounting between Germany and Poland over the future of <a href="/wiki/Danzig" title="Danzig" class="mw-redirect">Danzig</a>, the Germans turned to the Soviets, and signed the <a href="/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact" title="Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact">Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact</a>. Germany <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland" title="Invasion of Poland">invaded Poland</a> on 1 September 1939, prompting France and the United Kingdom to declare war on Germany on 3 September, opening the <a href="/w/index.php?title=European_Theatre_of_World_War_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="European Theatre of World War II (page does not exist)">European Theatre of World War II</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_465_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_465-139">[139]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Soviet_invasion_of_Poland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Soviet invasion of Poland (page does not exist)">Soviet invasion of Poland</a> started on 17 September and Poland fell soon thereafter. On 24 September, the Soviet Union attacked the <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Baltic_states" title="Occupation of the Baltic states">Baltic countries</a> and later, Finland. The British hoped to land at <a href="/wiki/Battles_of_Narvik" title="Battles of Narvik">Narvik</a> and send troops to aid Finland, but their primary objective in the landing was to encircle Germany and cut the Germans off from Scandinavian resources. Around the same time, Germany moved troops into Denmark. The <a href="/wiki/Phoney_War" title="Phoney War">Phoney War</a> continued.
</p><p>In May 1940, Germany <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_France" title="Battle of France">attacked France</a> through the Low Countries. France capitulated in June 1940. By August Germany began a <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Britain" title="Battle of Britain">bombing offensive on Britain</a>, but failed to convince the Britons to give up.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_510_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_510-141">[141]</a></sup> In 1941, Germany invaded the Soviet Union in the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">Operation Barbarossa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_532_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_532-142">[142]</a></sup> On 7 December 1941 <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Japan's</a> <a href="/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor" title="Attack on Pearl Harbor">attack on Pearl Harbor</a> drew the United States into the conflict as allies of the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">allied</a> forces.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_511_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_511-143">[143]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_519_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_519-144">[144]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Yalta_summit_1945_with_Churchill,_Roosevelt,_Stalin.jpg" title="File:Yalta summit 1945 with Churchill, Roosevelt, Stalin.jpg">File:Yalta summit 1945 with Churchill, Roosevelt, Stalin.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The "<a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Big Three</a>" at the <a href="/wiki/Yalta_Conference" title="Yalta Conference">Yalta Conference</a> in 1945; seated (from the left): <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a></div></div></div>
<p>After the staggering <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Stalingrad" title="Battle of Stalingrad">Battle of Stalingrad</a> in 1943, the German offensive in the Soviet Union turned into a continual fallback. The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kursk" title="Battle of Kursk">Battle of Kursk</a>, which involved the largest <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Prokhorovka" title="Battle of Prokhorovka">tank battle</a> in history, was the last major German offensive on the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">Eastern Front</a>. In 1944, British and American forces invaded France in the <a href="/wiki/Normandy_landings" title="Normandy landings">D-Day landings</a>, opening a new front against Germany. <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a> finally fell in 1945, ending World War II in Europe. The war was the largest and most destructive in human history, with <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties" title="World War II casualties">60&#160;million dead across the world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_439_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_439-145">[145]</a></sup> More than 40&#160;million people in Europe had died as a result of the war by the time World War II ended,<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup> including between 11 and 17&#160;million people who perished during <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Holocaust&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Holocaust (page does not exist)">the Holocaust</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup> The Soviet Union <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_II_casualties_of_the_Soviet_Union&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World War II casualties of the Soviet Union (page does not exist)">lost around 27&#160;million people</a> (mostly civilians) during the war, about half of all World War II casualties.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> By the end of World War II, Europe had more than 40&#160;million <a href="/wiki/Refugee" title="Refugee">refugees</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> Several <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_evacuation_and_expulsion" title="World War II evacuation and expulsion">post-war expulsions</a> in Central and Eastern Europe displaced a total of about 20&#160;million people.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Schuman_Declaration.jpg" title="File:Schuman Declaration.jpg">File:Schuman Declaration.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Schuman_Declaration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Schuman Declaration (page does not exist)">Schuman Declaration</a> led to the creation of the <a href="/wiki/European_Coal_and_Steel_Community" title="European Coal and Steel Community">European Coal and Steel Community</a>. It began the <a href="/wiki/European_integration" title="European integration">integration process</a> of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>. (<a href="/wiki/Europe_Day" title="Europe Day">9 May</a> 1950, at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=French_Foreign_Ministry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="French Foreign Ministry (page does not exist)">French Foreign Ministry</a>)</div></div></div>
<p>World War I and especially World War II diminished the eminence of Western Europe in world affairs. After World War II the map of Europe was redrawn at the <a href="/wiki/Yalta_Conference" title="Yalta Conference">Yalta Conference</a> and divided into two blocs, the Western countries and the communist Eastern bloc, separated by what was later called by <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> an "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Iron_Curtain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iron Curtain (page does not exist)">Iron Curtain</a>". The United States and Western Europe
established the <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> alliance and later the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe established the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Pact" title="Warsaw Pact">Warsaw Pact</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_530_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_530-151">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>The two new <a href="/wiki/Superpower" title="Superpower">superpowers</a>, the United States and the Soviet Union, became locked in a fifty-year long Cold War, centred on <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_proliferation" title="Nuclear proliferation">nuclear proliferation</a>. At the same time <a href="/wiki/Decolonisation" title="Decolonisation" class="mw-redirect">decolonisation</a>, which had already started after World War I, gradually resulted in the independence of most of the European colonies in Asia and Africa.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_534_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_534-6">[6]</a></sup>
In the 1980s the <a href="/wiki/Glasnost" title="Glasnost">reforms</a> of <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Solidarity_(Polish_trade_union)" title="Solidarity (Polish trade union)">Solidarity</a> movement in Poland accelerated the collapse of the Eastern bloc and the end of the Cold War. Germany was reunited, after the symbolic <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Berlin_Wall" title="Fall of the Berlin Wall" class="mw-redirect">fall of the Berlin Wall</a> in 1989, and the maps of Eastern Europe were redrawn once more.<sup id="cite_ref-hobsbawn_137-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hobsbawn-137">[137]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/European_integration" title="European integration">European integration</a> also grew after World War II. The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Rome" title="Treaty of Rome">Treaty of Rome</a> in 1957 established the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> between six Western European states with the goal of a unified economic policy and common market.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_536_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_536-152">[152]</a></sup> In 1967 the EEC, <a href="/wiki/European_Coal_and_Steel_Community" title="European Coal and Steel Community">European Coal and Steel Community</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Euratom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Euratom (page does not exist)">Euratom</a> formed the <a href="/wiki/European_Community" title="European Community" class="mw-redirect">European Community</a>, which in 1993 became the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>. The EU established a <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">parliament</a>, <a href="/wiki/European_Court_of_Justice" title="European Court of Justice">court</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_Central_Bank" title="European Central Bank">central bank</a> and introduced the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">euro</a> as a unified currency.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_537_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_537-153">[153]</a></sup> In 2004 and 2007, more Eastern European countries began joining, <a href="/wiki/Enlargement_of_the_European_Union" title="Enlargement of the European Union">expanding the EU</a> to its current size of 28 European countries, and once more making Europe a major economical and political centre of power.<sup id="cite_ref-natgeo_535_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natgeo_535-154">[154]</a></sup>
</p>
<table style="margin:auto;" class="toccolours">
<tr>
<td style="background:#f8eaba; text-align:center;">
<p>&lt;center&gt;
</p>
<dl>
<dt> European development
</dt>
</dl>
<p>&lt;/center&gt;
</p>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>

</p>
			</div>

</ul>
</td></tr></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europe_topography_map_en.png" title="File:Europe topography map en.png">File:Europe topography map en.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Relief map of Europe and surrounding regions</div></div></div>
<p>Europe is a peninsula that makes up the western fifth of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eurasia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eurasia (page does not exist)">Eurasian</a> landmass.<sup id="cite_ref-Encarta_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta-19">[19]</a></sup> Its maritime borders are made up of the Arctic Ocean to the north, the Atlantic Ocean to the west, and the Mediterranean, Black, and Caspian Seas to the south<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup>
Land relief in Europe shows great variation within relatively small areas. The southern regions are more mountainous, while moving north the terrain descends from the high <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">Alps</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pyrenees" title="Pyrenees">Pyrenees</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains" title="Carpathian Mountains">Carpathians</a>, through hilly uplands, into broad, low northern plains, which are vast in the east. This extended lowland is known as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_European_Plain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great European Plain (page does not exist)">Great European Plain</a>, and at its heart lies the <a href="/w/index.php?title=North_German_Plain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="North German Plain (page does not exist)">North German Plain</a>. An arc of uplands also exists along the north-western seaboard, which begins in the western parts of the islands of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Britain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Britain (page does not exist)">Britain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a>, and then continues along the mountainous, fjord-cut spine of Norway.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europe_land_use_map.png" title="File:Europe land use map.png">File:Europe land use map.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Land use map of Europe with arable farmland (yellow), forest (dark green), pasture (light green), and tundra or bogs in the north (dark yellow)</div></div></div>
<p>This description is simplified. Sub-regions such as the <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Peninsula" title="Italian Peninsula">Italian Peninsula</a> contain their own complex features, as does mainland Central Europe itself, where the relief contains many plateaus, river valleys and basins that complicate the general trend. Sub-regions like <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a>, Britain, and Ireland are special cases. The former is a land unto itself in the northern ocean which is counted as part of Europe, while the latter are upland areas that were once joined to the mainland until rising sea levels cut them off.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vegetation_Europe.png" title="File:Vegetation Europe.png">File:Vegetation Europe.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Biome" title="Biome">Biomes</a> of Europe and surrounding regions: <br /> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend0&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend0 (page does not exist)">Template:Legend0</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend0&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend0 (page does not exist)">Template:Legend0</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend0&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend0 (page does not exist)">Template:Legend0</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend0&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend0 (page does not exist)">Template:Legend0</a> <br /> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend0&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend0 (page does not exist)">Template:Legend0</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend0&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend0 (page does not exist)">Template:Legend0</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend0&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend0 (page does not exist)">Template:Legend0</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend0&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend0 (page does not exist)">Template:Legend0</a></div></div></div>
<p>Europe lies mainly in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Temperate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Temperate (page does not exist)">temperate</a> climate zones, being subjected to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Prevailing_westerlies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Prevailing westerlies (page does not exist)">prevailing westerlies</a>.
</p><p>The climate is milder in comparison to other areas of the same latitude around the globe due to the influence of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gulf_Stream&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gulf Stream (page does not exist)">Gulf Stream</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-climate_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climate-156">[156]</a></sup> The Gulf Stream is nicknamed "Europe's central heating", because it makes Europe's climate warmer and wetter than it would otherwise be. The Gulf Stream not only carries warm water to Europe's coast but also warms up the prevailing westerly winds that blow across the continent from the Atlantic Ocean.
</p><p>Therefore the average temperature throughout the year of Naples is 16&#160;°C (60.8&#160;°F), while it is only 12&#160;°C (53.6&#160;°F) in New York City which is almost on the same latitude. Berlin, Germany; Calgary, Canada; and Irkutsk, in the Asian part of Russia, lie on around the same latitude; January temperatures in Berlin average around 8&#160;°C (15&#160;°F) higher than those in Calgary, and they are almost 22&#160;°C (40&#160;°F) higher than average temperatures in Irkutsk.<sup id="cite_ref-climate_156-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-climate-156">[156]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Geology">Geology</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The Geology of Europe is hugely varied and complex, and gives rise to the wide variety of landscapes found across the continent, from the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Highlands" title="Scottish Highlands">Scottish Highlands</a> to the rolling <a href="/wiki/Plain" title="Plain">plains</a> of Hungary.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tatry_widok_z_Tarasowek.jpg" title="File:Tatry widok z Tarasowek.jpg">File:Tatry widok z Tarasowek.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Western <a href="/wiki/Carpathians" title="Carpathians" class="mw-redirect">Carpathians</a> in Poland</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Landscapes_of_Croatia-04.jpg" title="File:Landscapes of Croatia-04.jpg">File:Landscapes of Croatia-04.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adriatic_Sea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adriatic Sea (page does not exist)">Adriatic Sea</a> contains over 1300 islands and islets</div></div></div>
<p>Europe's most significant feature is the dichotomy between highland and mountainous <a href="/wiki/Southern_Europe" title="Southern Europe">Southern Europe</a> and a vast, partially underwater, northern plain ranging from Ireland in the west to the <a href="/wiki/Ural_Mountains" title="Ural Mountains">Ural Mountains</a> in the east. These two halves are separated by the mountain chains of the <a href="/wiki/Pyrenees" title="Pyrenees">Pyrenees</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">Alps</a>/<a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains" title="Carpathian Mountains">Carpathians</a>. The northern plains are delimited in the west by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scandinavian_Mountains&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scandinavian Mountains (page does not exist)">Scandinavian Mountains</a> and the mountainous parts of the British Isles. Major shallow water bodies submerging parts of the northern plains are the <a href="/wiki/Celtic_Sea" title="Celtic Sea">Celtic Sea</a>, the <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a> complex and <a href="/wiki/Barents_Sea" title="Barents Sea">Barents Sea</a>.
</p><p>The northern plain contains the old geological continent of <a href="/wiki/Baltica" title="Baltica">Baltica</a>, and so may be regarded geologically as the "main continent", while peripheral highlands and mountainous regions in the south and west constitute fragments from various other geological continents. Most of the older geology of western Europe existed as part of the ancient <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microcontinent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microcontinent (page does not exist)">microcontinent</a> <a href="/wiki/Avalonia" title="Avalonia">Avalonia</a>.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Geological_history">Geological history</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The geological history of Europe traces back to the formation of the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Shield" title="Baltic Shield" class="mw-redirect">Baltic Shield</a> (Fennoscandia) and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sarmatian_craton&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sarmatian craton (page does not exist)">Sarmatian craton</a>, both around 2.25&#160;billion years ago, followed by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Volgo-Uralia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Volgo-Uralia (page does not exist)">Volgo-Uralia</a> shield, the three together leading to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_European_craton&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East European craton (page does not exist)">East European craton</a> (≈ <a href="/wiki/Baltica" title="Baltica">Baltica</a>) which became a part of the <a href="/wiki/Supercontinent" title="Supercontinent">supercontinent</a> <a href="/wiki/Columbia_(supercontinent)" title="Columbia (supercontinent)">Columbia</a>. Around 1.1&#160;billion years ago, Baltica and Arctica (as part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Laurentia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Laurentia (page does not exist)">Laurentia</a> block) became joined to <a href="/wiki/Rodinia" title="Rodinia">Rodinia</a>, later resplitting around 550&#160;million years ago to reform as Baltica. Around 440&#160;million years ago <a href="/wiki/Euramerica" title="Euramerica">Euramerica</a> was formed from Baltica and Laurentia; a further joining with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gondwana&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gondwana (page does not exist)">Gondwana</a> then leading to the formation of <a href="/wiki/Pangea" title="Pangea" class="mw-redirect">Pangea</a>. Around 190&#160;million years ago, Gondwana and <a href="/wiki/Laurasia" title="Laurasia">Laurasia</a> split apart due to the widening of the Atlantic Ocean. Finally, and very soon afterwards, Laurasia itself split up again, into Laurentia (North America) and the Eurasian continent. The land connection between the two persisted for a considerable time, via <a href="/wiki/Greenland" title="Greenland">Greenland</a>, leading to interchange of animal species. From around 50&#160;million years ago, rising and falling sea levels have determined the actual shape of Europe, and its connections with continents such as Asia. Europe's present shape dates to the late <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_period" title="Tertiary period" class="mw-redirect">Tertiary period</a> about five million years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-Encyclop.C3.A6dia_Britannica_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclop.C3.A6dia_Britannica-158">[158]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europe_biogeography_countries.svg" title="File:Europe biogeography countries.svg">File:Europe biogeography countries.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Biogeography" title="Biogeography">Biogeographic regions</a> of Europe and bordering regions</div></div></div>
<p>Having lived side-by-side with agricultural peoples for millennia, Europe's animals and plants have been profoundly affected by the presence and activities of man. With the exception of <a href="/wiki/Fennoscandia" title="Fennoscandia">Fennoscandia</a> and northern Russia, few areas of untouched wilderness are currently found in Europe, except for various <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">national parks</a>.
</p><p>The main natural vegetation cover in Europe is mixed <a href="/wiki/Forest" title="Forest">forest</a>. The conditions for growth are very favourable. In the north, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gulf_Stream&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gulf Stream (page does not exist)">Gulf Stream</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_Current" title="North Atlantic Current">North Atlantic Drift</a> warm the continent. Southern Europe could be described as having a warm, but mild climate. There are frequent summer droughts in this region. Mountain ridges also affect the conditions. Some of these (<a href="/wiki/Alps" title="Alps">Alps</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pyrenees" title="Pyrenees">Pyrenees</a>) are oriented east-west and allow the wind to carry large masses of water from the ocean in the interior. Others are oriented south-north (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Scandinavian_Mountains&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scandinavian Mountains (page does not exist)">Scandinavian Mountains</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dinaric_Alps" title="Dinaric Alps">Dinarides</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains" title="Carpathian Mountains">Carpathians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Apennine_Mountains" title="Apennine Mountains">Apennines</a>) and because the rain falls primarily on the side of mountains that is oriented towards the sea, forests grow well on this side, while on the other side, the conditions are much less favourable. Few corners of mainland Europe have not been grazed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Livestock&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Livestock (page does not exist)">livestock</a> at some point in time, and the cutting down of the pre-agricultural forest habitat caused disruption to the original plant and animal ecosystems.
</p><p>Probably 80 to 90 per cent of Europe was once covered by forest.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup> It stretched from the Mediterranean Sea to the Arctic Ocean. Though over half of Europe's original forests disappeared through the centuries of <a href="/wiki/Deforestation" title="Deforestation">deforestation</a>, Europe still has over one quarter of its land area as forest, such as the <a href="/wiki/Taiga" title="Taiga">taiga</a> of Scandinavia and Russia, mixed <a href="/wiki/Rainforest" title="Rainforest">rainforests</a> of the Caucasus and the <a href="/wiki/Cork_oak" title="Cork oak" class="mw-redirect">Cork oak</a> forests in the western Mediterranean. During recent times, deforestation has been slowed and many trees have been planted. However, in many cases monoculture <a href="/wiki/Plantation" title="Plantation">plantations</a> of <a href="/wiki/Pinophyta" title="Pinophyta">conifers</a> have replaced the original mixed natural forest, because these grow quicker. The plantations now cover vast areas of land, but offer poorer habitats for many European forest dwelling species which require a mixture of tree species and diverse forest structure. The amount of natural forest in Western Europe is just 2–3% or less, in European Russia 5–10%. The country with the smallest percentage of forested area is <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a> (1%), while the most forested country is Finland (77%).<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Floristic_regions_in_Europe_(english).png" title="File:Floristic regions in Europe (english).png">File:Floristic regions in Europe (english).png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Floristic regions of Europe and neighbouring areas, according to Wolfgang Frey and Rainer Lösch</div></div></div>
<p>In temperate Europe, mixed forest with both <a href="/wiki/Flowering_plant" title="Flowering plant">broadleaf</a> and coniferous trees dominate. The most important species in central and western Europe are <a href="/wiki/Beech" title="Beech">beech</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oak" title="Oak">oak</a>. In the north, the taiga is a mixed <a href="/wiki/Spruce" title="Spruce">spruce</a>–<a href="/wiki/Pine" title="Pine">pine</a>–<a href="/wiki/Birch" title="Birch">birch</a> forest; further north within Russia and extreme northern Scandinavia, the taiga gives way to <a href="/wiki/Tundra" title="Tundra">tundra</a> as the Arctic is approached. In the Mediterranean, many <a href="/wiki/Olive" title="Olive">olive</a> trees have been planted, which are very well adapted to its arid climate; <a href="/wiki/Cupressus_sempervirens" title="Cupressus sempervirens">Mediterranean Cypress</a> is also widely planted in southern Europe. The semi-arid Mediterranean region hosts much scrub forest. A narrow east-west tongue of Eurasian <a href="/wiki/Grassland" title="Grassland">grassland</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Steppe" title="Steppe">steppe</a>) extends eastwards from <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> and southern Russia and ends in Hungary and traverses into taiga to the north.
</p><p>Glaciation during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Quaternary_glaciation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Quaternary glaciation (page does not exist)">most recent ice age</a> and the presence of man affected the distribution of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fauna_of_Europe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fauna of Europe (page does not exist)">European fauna</a>. As for the animals, in many parts of Europe most large animals and top <a href="/w/index.php?title=Predator&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Predator (page does not exist)">predator</a> species have been hunted to extinction. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Woolly_mammoth&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Woolly mammoth (page does not exist)">woolly mammoth</a> was extinct before the end of the <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> period. Today <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wolf&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wolf (page does not exist)">wolves</a> (<a href="/wiki/Carnivore" title="Carnivore">carnivores</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Bear" title="Bear">bears</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Omnivore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Omnivore (page does not exist)">omnivores</a>) are endangered. Once they were found in most parts of Europe. However, deforestation and hunting caused these animals to withdraw further and further. By the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a> the bears' habitats were limited to more or less inaccessible mountains with sufficient forest cover. Today, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=European_brown_bear&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="European brown bear (page does not exist)">brown bear</a> lives primarily in the <a href="/wiki/Balkan" title="Balkan" class="mw-redirect">Balkan peninsula</a>, Scandinavia, and Russia; a small number also persist in other countries across Europe (Austria, Pyrenees etc.), but in these areas brown bear populations are fragmented and marginalised because of the destruction of their habitat. In addition, <a href="/wiki/Polar_bear" title="Polar bear">polar bears</a> may be found on <a href="/wiki/Svalbard" title="Svalbard">Svalbard</a>, a Norwegian archipelago far north of Scandinavia. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eurasian_wolf&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eurasian wolf (page does not exist)">wolf</a>, the second largest predator in Europe after the brown bear, can be found primarily in <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a> and in the Balkans, with a handful of packs in pockets of <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a> (Scandinavia, Spain, etc.).
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Neandertal_-_Wisent.jpg" title="File:Neandertal - Wisent.jpg">File:Neandertal - Wisent.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Once roaming the great temperate forests of Eurasia, <a href="/wiki/European_bison" title="European bison">European bison</a> now live in nature preserves in <a href="/wiki/Bia%C5%82owie%C5%BCa_Forest" title="Białowieża Forest">Białowieża Forest</a>, on the border between <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>European wild cat, foxes (especially the red fox), jackal and different species of martens, hedgehogs, different species of reptiles (like snakes such as vipers and grass snakes) and amphibians, different birds (owls, hawks and other birds of prey).
</p><p>Important European herbivores are snails, larvae, fish, different birds, and mammals, like rodents, deer and roe deer, boars, and living in the mountains, marmots, steinbocks, chamois among others.  A number of insects, such as the <a href="/wiki/Small_tortoiseshell" title="Small tortoiseshell" class="mw-redirect">small tortoiseshell</a> butterfly, add to the biodiversity.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup>
</p><p>The extinction of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cretan_Dwarf_Hippopotamus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cretan Dwarf Hippopotamus (page does not exist)">dwarf hippos</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dwarf_elephant" title="Dwarf elephant">dwarf elephants</a> has been linked to the earliest arrival of humans on the islands of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mediterranean&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mediterranean (page does not exist)">Mediterranean</a>.
</p><p>Sea creatures are also an important part of European flora and fauna. The sea flora is mainly <a href="/wiki/Phytoplankton" title="Phytoplankton">phytoplankton</a>. Important animals that live in European seas are <a href="/wiki/Zooplankton" title="Zooplankton">zooplankton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mollusc" title="Mollusc" class="mw-redirect">molluscs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Echinoderm" title="Echinoderm">echinoderms</a>, different <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crustacean&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crustacean (page does not exist)">crustaceans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Squid" title="Squid">squids</a> and <a href="/wiki/Octopuses" title="Octopuses" class="mw-redirect">octopuses</a>, fish, <a href="/wiki/Dolphin" title="Dolphin">dolphins</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Whales" title="Whales" class="mw-redirect">whales</a>.
</p><p>Biodiversity is protected in Europe through the Council of Europe's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Convention_on_the_Conservation_of_European_Wildlife_and_Natural_Habitats&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats (page does not exist)">Bern Convention</a>, which has also been signed by the <a href="/wiki/European_Community" title="European Community" class="mw-redirect">European Community</a> as well as non-European states.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_geography">Political geography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<table>
<tr>
<td> <div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europe_Asia_transcontinental.png" title="File:Europe Asia transcontinental.png">File:Europe Asia transcontinental.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend (page does not exist)">Template:Legend</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Legend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Legend (page does not exist)">Template:Legend</a></div></div></div>
</td>
<td> <div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europe_countries_map_en_2.png" title="File:Europe countries map en 2.png">File:Europe countries map en 2.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Modern <a href="/w/index.php?title=Political_map&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Political map (page does not exist)">political map</a> of Europe and the surrounding region</div></div></div>
</td>
<td> <div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europe_subregion_map_UN_geoschme.svg" title="File:Europe subregion map UN geoschme.svg">File:Europe subregion map UN geoschme.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Regional grouping used by the United Nations Statistics Department.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup></div></div></div>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europe_subregion_map_world_factbook.svg" title="File:Europe subregion map world factbook.svg">File:Europe subregion map world factbook.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Regional grouping according to <a href="/wiki/The_World_Factbook" title="The World Factbook">The World Factbook</a></div></div></div>
</td>
<td> <div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:EU28-candidate_countries_map.svg" title="File:EU28-candidate countries map.svg">File:EU28-candidate countries map.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> and its candidate countries</div></div></div>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Map-Coeurope.jpg" title="File:Map-Coeurope.jpg">File:Map-Coeurope.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> nations</div></div></div>
</td>
<td> <div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:EU_and_NATO.svg" title="File:EU and NATO.svg">File:EU and NATO.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Map showing European membership of the EU and NATO</div></div></div>
</td></tr></table>
<p>The list below includes all entities falling even partially under any of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Geopolitical_divisions_of_Europe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Geopolitical divisions of Europe (page does not exist)">various common definitions of Europe</a>, geographic or political. The data displayed are per sources in cross-referenced articles. The 28 <a href="/w/index.php?title=European_Union_member_state&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="European Union member state (page does not exist)">European Union member states</a> are highly integrated, economically and politically; the European Union itself forms part of the political geography of Europe.
</p>
<table class="references-small sortable wikitable">

</td>
<td> Sverige
</td></tr>
<tr>

</td>
<td style="text-align:right;"> 10,180,000<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cref2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cref2 (page does not exist)">Template:Cref2</a>

</td>
<td style="text-align:right;"> 70
</td></tr></table>
<p>Within the above-mentioned states are several <a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">de facto</a> independent countries with <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_limited_recognition" title="List of states with limited recognition">limited to no international recognition</a>. None of them are members of the UN:
</p>
<table class="references-small sortable wikitable">

<p>Several dependencies and similar territories with broad autonomy are also found in Europe. Note that the list does not include the constituent countries of the United Kingdom, federal states of Germany and Austria, and autonomous territories of Spain and the post-Soviet republics as well as the republic of Serbia.
</p>
