</td></tr></table>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Integration">Integration</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:EU_CIS.PNG" title="File:EU CIS.PNG">File:EU CIS.PNG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Commonwealth of Independent States">Commonwealth of Independent States</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
European integration is the process of political, legal, economic (and in some cases social and cultural) integration of states wholly or partially in Europe. In the present day, European integration has primarily come about through the Council of Europe and European Union in Western and Central Europe and <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Commonwealth of Independent States">Commonwealth of Independent States</a> in Eastern Europe and most of former Soviet countries.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Europe_gdp_map-1-.png" title="File:Europe gdp map-1-.png">File:Europe gdp map-1-.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">European and bordering nations by <a href="/w/index.php?title=GDP&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="GDP (page does not exist)">GDP</a> (nominal) per capita in 2012</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
As a continent, the economy of Europe is currently the largest on Earth and it is the richest region as measured by assets under management with over $32.7&#160;trillion compared to North America's $27.1&#160;trillion in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup> In 2009 Europe remained the wealthiest region. Its $37.1 trillion in assets under management represented one-third of the world's wealth. It was one of several regions where wealth surpassed its precrisis year-end peak.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup> As with other continents, Europe has a large variation of wealth among its countries. The richer states tend to be in the <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">West</a>; some of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern</a> economies are still emerging from the collapse of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=SFR_Yugoslavia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="SFR Yugoslavia (page does not exist)">Yugoslavia</a>.
</p><p>The European Union, an intergovernmental body composed of 27 European states, comprises the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_GDP&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by GDP (page does not exist)">largest single economic area</a> in the world. 16 EU <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">countries</a> share the <a href="/wiki/Euro" title="Euro">euro</a> as a common currency.
Five European countries rank in the top ten of the world's largest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">national economies in GDP (PPP)</a>. This includes (ranks according to the <a href="/wiki/The_CIA_World_Factbook" title="The CIA World Factbook" class="mw-redirect">CIA</a>): Germany (5), the UK (6), Russia (7), France (8), and Italy (10).<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup>
</p><p>There is huge disparity between many European countries in terms of their income. The richest in terms of GDP per capita is Monaco with its US$172,676 per capita (2009) and the poorest is Moldova with its GDP per capita of US$1,631 (2010).<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Monaco" title="Monaco">Monaco</a> is the richest country in terms of GDP per capita in the world according to the World Bank report.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre.E2.80.931945:_Industrial_growth">Pre–1945: Industrial growth</span></h3>
<p>Capitalism has been dominant in the Western world since the end of feudalism.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> From Britain, it gradually spread throughout Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> started in Europe, specifically the United Kingdom in the late 18th century,<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> and the 19th century saw Western Europe industrialise. Economies were disrupted by World War I but by the beginning of World War II they had recovered and were having to compete with the growing economic strength of the United States. World War II, again, damaged much of Europe's industries.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1945.E2.80.931990:_The_Cold_War">1945–1990: The Cold War</span></h3>
<p>After World War II the economy of the UK was in a state of ruin,<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup> and continued to suffer relative economic decline in the following decades.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup> Italy was also in a poor economic condition but regained a high level of growth by the 1950s. West Germany <a href="/wiki/Wirtschaftswunder" title="Wirtschaftswunder">recovered quickly</a> and had doubled production from pre-war levels by the 1950s.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup> France also staged a remarkable comeback enjoying rapid growth and modernisation; later on Spain, under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Francisco_Franco" title="Francisco Franco">Franco</a>, also recovered, and the nation recorded huge unprecedented economic growth beginning in the 1960s in what is called the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_miracle" title="Spanish miracle">Spanish miracle</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> The majority of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern European</a> states came under the control of the <a href="/wiki/USSR" title="USSR" class="mw-redirect">USSR</a> and thus were members of the <a href="/wiki/Council_for_Mutual_Economic_Assistance" title="Council for Mutual Economic Assistance" class="mw-redirect">Council for Mutual Economic Assistance</a> (COMECON).<sup id="cite_ref-loc-cs_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-loc-cs-177">[177]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Thefalloftheberlinwall1989.JPG" title="File:Thefalloftheberlinwall1989.JPG">File:Thefalloftheberlinwall1989.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Fall of the <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Wall" title="Berlin Wall">Berlin Wall</a> in 1989.</div></div></div>
<p>The states which retained a <a href="/wiki/Free-market" title="Free-market" class="mw-redirect">free-market</a> system were given a large amount of aid by the United States under the <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Plan" title="Marshall Plan">Marshall Plan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup> The western states moved to link their economies together, providing the basis for the EU and increasing cross border trade. This helped them to enjoy rapidly improving economies, while those states in COMECON were struggling in a large part due to the cost of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>. Until 1990, the <a href="/wiki/European_Community" title="European Community" class="mw-redirect">European Community</a> was expanded from 6 founding members to 12. The emphasis placed on resurrecting the West German economy led to it overtaking the UK as Europe's largest economy.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1991.E2.80.932007:_Integration_and_reunification">1991–2007: Integration and reunification</span></h3>
<p>With the fall of communism in Eastern Europe in 1991, the post-socialist states began free market reforms: Poland, Hungary, and <a href="/wiki/Slovenia" title="Slovenia">Slovenia</a> adopted them reasonably quickly, while <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> and Russia are still in the process of doing so.
</p><p>After <a href="/wiki/East_Germany" title="East Germany">East</a> and West Germany were reunited in 1990, the economy of West Germany struggled as it had to support and largely rebuild the infrastructure of East Germany.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Unemployment_European_Union_2010M09.svg" title="File:Unemployment European Union 2010M09.svg">File:Unemployment European Union 2010M09.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Unemployment in the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> in 2010, according to <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>By the millennium change, the EU dominated the economy of Europe comprising the five largest European economies of the time namely Germany, the United Kingdom, France, Italy, and Spain. In 1999, 12 of the 15 members of the EU joined the <a href="/wiki/Eurozone" title="Eurozone">Eurozone</a> replacing their former national currencies by the common euro. The three who chose to remain outside the Eurozone were: the United Kingdom, Denmark, and Sweden.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2008.E2.80.932010:_Recession">2008–2010: Recession</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Recentism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Recentism (page does not exist)">Template:Recentism</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The Eurozone entered its first official <a href="/wiki/Recession" title="Recession">recession</a> in the third quarter of 2008, official figures confirmed in January 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> While beginning in the United States the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Late-2000s_recession&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Late-2000s recession (page does not exist)">late-2000s recession</a> spread to Europe rapidly and has affected much of the region.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=EU-27&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="EU-27 (page does not exist)">EU-27</a> unemployment rate was 10.3% in April 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-unemployment_181-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unemployment-181">[181]</a></sup> Europe's young workers have been especially hard hit.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> In April 2012, the unemployment rate in the EU27 for those aged 15–24 was 22.4%.<sup id="cite_ref-unemployment_181-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unemployment-181">[181]</a></sup>
</p><p>In early 2010, fears of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=European_sovereign-debt_crisis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="European sovereign-debt crisis (page does not exist)">sovereign debt crisis</a><sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> developed concerning some countries in Europe, especially Greece, Ireland, Spain, and Portugal.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup> As a result, measures were taken especially for Greece by the leading countries of the Eurozone.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Demographics_of_Europe.svg" title="File:Demographics of Europe.svg">File:Demographics of Europe.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Population_growth" title="Population growth">Population growth</a> and decline in and around Europe in 2010<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Since the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a>, Europe has had a major influence in culture, economics and social movements in the world. The most significant <a href="/wiki/Invention" title="Invention">inventions</a> had their origins in the Western world, primarily Europe and the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup> Approximately 70 million Europeans died through war, violence and famine between 1914 and 1945.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> Some current and past issues in European demographics have included <a href="/wiki/Emigration" title="Emigration">religious emigration</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Race_relations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Race relations (page does not exist)">race relations</a>, <a href="/wiki/Economic_migrant" title="Economic migrant">economic immigration</a>, a declining <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">birth rate</a> and an <a href="/wiki/Aging_population" title="Aging population" class="mw-redirect">aging population</a>.
</p><p>In some countries, such as <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" title="Republic of Ireland">Ireland</a> and Poland, access to <a href="/wiki/Abortion" title="Abortion">abortion</a> is limited. It remains illegal on the island of <a href="/wiki/Malta" title="Malta">Malta</a>. Furthermore, three European countries (the Netherlands, Belgium, and Switzerland) and the <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_Community" title="Autonomous Community" class="mw-redirect">Autonomous Community</a> of <a href="/wiki/Andalusia" title="Andalusia">Andalusia</a> (Spain)<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> have allowed a limited form of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Voluntary_euthanasia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Voluntary euthanasia (page does not exist)">voluntary euthanasia</a> for some terminally ill people.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Moravian_Slovak_Costumes_during_Jizda_Kralu.jpg" title="File:Moravian Slovak Costumes during Jizda Kralu.jpg">File:Moravian Slovak Costumes during Jizda Kralu.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Moravian_Slovakia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Moravian Slovakia (page does not exist)">Moravian Slovak</a> costumes during festival</div></div></div>
<p>In 2005, the population of Europe was estimated to be 731&#160;million according to the United Nations,<sup id="cite_ref-UNPP_2006_192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNPP_2006-192">[192]</a></sup> which is slightly more than one-ninth of the world's population. A century ago, Europe had nearly a quarter of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_population&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World population (page does not exist)">world's population</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-World_Population_Growth.2C_1950.E2.80.932050_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Population_Growth.2C_1950.E2.80.932050-193">[193]</a></sup> The population of Europe has grown in the past century, but in other areas of the world (in particular Africa and Asia) the population has grown far more quickly.<sup id="cite_ref-UNPP_2006_192-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNPP_2006-192">[192]</a></sup> Among the continents, Europe has a relatively high <a href="/wiki/Population_density" title="Population density">population density</a>, second only to Asia. The most densely populated country in Europe (and in the world) is <a href="/wiki/Monaco" title="Monaco">Monaco</a>. Pan and Pfeil (2004) count 87 distinct "peoples of Europe", of which 33 form the majority population in at least one sovereign state, while the remaining 54 constitute <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_minority" title="Ethnic minority" class="mw-redirect">ethnic minorities</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup>
According to UN population projection, Europe's population may fall to about 7% of world population by 2050, or 653&#160;million people (medium variant, 556 to 777&#160;million in low and high variants, respectively).<sup id="cite_ref-UNPP_2006_192-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNPP_2006-192">[192]</a></sup> Within this context, significant disparities exist between regions in relation to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Human_overpopulation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Human overpopulation (page does not exist)">fertility rates</a>. The average number of <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_and_territories_by_fertility_rate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries and territories by fertility rate (page does not exist)">children per female</a> of child bearing age is 1.52.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> According to some sources,<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> this rate is higher among <a href="/w/index.php?title=Islam_in_Europe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Islam in Europe (page does not exist)">Muslims in Europe</a>. The UN predicts the steady <a href="/wiki/Population_decline" title="Population decline">population decline</a> of vast areas of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gaiteiros_em_romaria_galega.jpg" title="File:Gaiteiros em romaria galega.jpg">File:Gaiteiros em romaria galega.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Galician bagpipers or <i><a href="/wiki/Galician_gaita" title="Galician gaita">gaiteiros</a></i> in Spain</div></div></div>
<p>Europe is home to the highest number of migrants of all global regions at 70.6 million people, the <a href="/wiki/International_Organisation_for_Migration" title="International Organisation for Migration" class="mw-redirect">IOM</a>'s report said.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup> In 2005, the EU had an overall net gain from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Immigration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Immigration (page does not exist)">immigration</a> of 1.8&#160;million people. This accounted for almost 85% of Europe's total <a href="/wiki/Population_growth" title="Population growth">population growth</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup> The European Union plans to open the job centres for legal migrant workers from Africa.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> In 2008, 696,000 persons were given citizenship of an EU27 member state, a decrease from 707,000 the previous year. The largest groups that acquired citizenship of an EU member state were citizens of Morocco, Turkey, <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>, Algeria and Iraq.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Emigration_from_Europe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Emigration from Europe (page does not exist)">Emigration from Europe</a> began with Spanish and Portuguese settlers in the 16th century,<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ppghis.ifcs.ufrj.br_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ppghis.ifcs.ufrj.br-204">[204]</a></sup> and French and English settlers in the 17th century.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup> But numbers remained relatively small until waves of mass emigration in the 19th century, when millions of poor families left Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup>
</p><p>Today, large populations of European descent are found on every continent. European ancestry predominates in North America, and to a lesser degree in South America (particularly in <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">Uruguay</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Argentina (page does not exist)">Argentina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">Chile</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>, while most of the other <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin American</a> countries also have a considerable <a href="/w/index.php?title=White_Latin_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White Latin American (page does not exist)">population of European origins</a>). <a href="/w/index.php?title=Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Australia (page does not exist)">Australia</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Zealand (page does not exist)">New Zealand</a> have large European derived populations. Africa has no countries with European-derived majorities (or with the exception of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cape_Verde&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cape Verde (page does not exist)">Cape Verde</a> and probably <a href="/w/index.php?title=S%C3%A3o_Tom%C3%A9_and_Pr%C3%ADncipe&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="São Tomé and Príncipe (page does not exist)">São Tomé and Príncipe</a>, depending on context), but there are significant minorities, such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=White_South_African&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White South African (page does not exist)">White South Africans</a>. In Asia, European-derived populations predominate in <a href="/wiki/Northern_Asia" title="Northern Asia" class="mw-redirect">Northern Asia</a> (specifically <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a>), some parts of Northern <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Israel (page does not exist)">Israel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup> Additionally, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Transcontinental_country&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Transcontinental country (page does not exist)">transcontinental</a> or geographically Asian countries such as <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Armenia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Armenia (page does not exist)">Armenia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turkey (page does not exist)">Turkey</a> have populations historically closely related to Europeans, with considerable genetic and cultural affinity.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rectified_Languages_of_Europe_map.png" title="File:Rectified Languages of Europe map.png">File:Rectified Languages of Europe map.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Map of major European languages</div></div></div>
<p>European languages mostly fall within three <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_languages" title="Indo-European languages">Indo-European</a> language groups: the <a href="/wiki/Romance_languages" title="Romance languages">Romance languages</a>, derived from the <a href="/wiki/Latin_language" title="Latin language" class="mw-redirect">Latin</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Germanic_languages" title="Germanic languages">Germanic languages</a>, whose ancestor language came from southern Scandinavia; and the <a href="/wiki/Slavic_languages" title="Slavic languages">Slavic languages</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Encyclop.C3.A6dia_Britannica_158-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclop.C3.A6dia_Britannica-158">[158]</a></sup>
</p><p>Slavic languages are most spoken by the number of native speakers in Europe, they are spoken in Central, Eastern, and Southeastern Europe. Romance languages are spoken primarily in south-western Europe as well as in <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a> and <a href="/wiki/Moldova" title="Moldova">Moldova</a>, in Central or Eastern Europe. Germanic languages are spoken in Northern Europe, the British Isles and some parts of <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Encyclop.C3.A6dia_Britannica_158-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclop.C3.A6dia_Britannica-158">[158]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many other languages outside the three main groups exist in Europe. Other Indo-European languages include the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_languages" title="Baltic languages">Baltic</a> group (that is, <a href="/wiki/Latvian_language" title="Latvian language">Latvian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lithuanian_language" title="Lithuanian language">Lithuanian</a>), the <a href="/wiki/Celtic_languages" title="Celtic languages">Celtic</a> group (that is, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Irish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Irish language (page does not exist)">Irish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scots_Gaelic_language" title="Scots Gaelic language" class="mw-redirect">Scottish Gaelic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manx_language" title="Manx language">Manx</a>, <a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cornish_language" title="Cornish language">Cornish</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Breton_language" title="Breton language">Breton</a><sup id="cite_ref-Encyclop.C3.A6dia_Britannica_158-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Encyclop.C3.A6dia_Britannica-158">[158]</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armenian_language" title="Armenian language">Armenian</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Albanian_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Albanian language (page does not exist)">Albanian</a>. In addition, a distinct group of <a href="/wiki/Uralic_languages" title="Uralic languages">Uralic languages</a> (<a href="/wiki/Estonian_language" title="Estonian language">Estonian</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Finnish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Finnish language (page does not exist)">Finnish</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">Hungarian</a>) is spoken mainly in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Estonia (page does not exist)">Estonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">Hungary</a>, while <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kartvelian_languages&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kartvelian languages (page does not exist)">Kartvelian languages</a> (<a href="/wiki/Georgian_language" title="Georgian language">Georgian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mingrelian_language" title="Mingrelian language">Mingrelian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Svan_language" title="Svan language">Svan</a>), are spoken primarily in <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>, and two other language families reside in the North Caucasus (termed <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Caucasian_languages" title="Northeast Caucasian languages">Northeast Caucasian</a>, most notably including <a href="/wiki/Chechen_language" title="Chechen language">Chechen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Avar_language" title="Avar language">Avar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lezgian_language" title="Lezgian language">Lezgin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northwest_Caucasian_languages" title="Northwest Caucasian languages">Northwest Caucasian</a>, notably including <a href="/wiki/Adyghe_language" title="Adyghe language">Adyghe</a>). <a href="/wiki/Maltese_language" title="Maltese language">Maltese</a> is the only <a href="/wiki/Semitic_language" title="Semitic language" class="mw-redirect">Semitic language</a> that is official within the EU, while <a href="/wiki/Basque_language" title="Basque language">Basque</a> is the only European <a href="/wiki/Language_isolate" title="Language isolate">language isolate</a>. <a href="/wiki/Turkic_languages" title="Turkic languages">Turkic languages</a> include <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijani_language" title="Azerbaijani language">Azerbaijani</a> and <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish</a>, in addition to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Languages_of_Russia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Languages of Russia (page does not exist)">languages of minority nations</a> in Russia.
</p><p>Multilingualism and the protection of regional and minority languages are recognized political goals in Europe today. The <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> <a href="/wiki/Framework_Convention_for_the_Protection_of_National_Minorities" title="Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities">Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities</a> and the Council of Europe's <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_for_Regional_or_Minority_Languages" title="European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages">European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages</a> set up a legal framework for language rights in Europe.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Petersdom_von_Engelsburg_gesehen.jpg" title="File:Petersdom von Engelsburg gesehen.jpg">File:Petersdom von Engelsburg gesehen.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/St._Peter%27s_Basilica" title="St. Peter's Basilica">St. Peter's Basilica</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a>, the largest European Roman Catholic church</div></div></div> 
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/History_of_religion" title="History of religion" class="mw-redirect">Historically</a>, religion in Europe has been a major influence on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Western_art_history&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Western art history (page does not exist)">European art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Europe" title="Culture of Europe">culture</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Western_philosophy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Western philosophy (page does not exist)">philosophy</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_Union_law" title="European Union law">law</a>. The largest religion in Europe is <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, with 76.2% of Europeans considering themselves <a href="/w/index.php?title=Christian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Christian (page does not exist)">Christians</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup> including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Catholic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Catholic (page does not exist)">Catholic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Protestantism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Protestantism (page does not exist)">Protestant</a> Churches. Following these is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Islam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Islam (page does not exist)">Islam</a> concentrated mainly in the Balkans and eastern Europe (<a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Albania" title="Albania">Albania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kosovo" title="Kosovo">Kosovo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a>, <a href="/wiki/TRNC" title="TRNC" class="mw-redirect">North Cyprus</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Turkey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Turkey (page does not exist)">Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_Caucasus" title="North Caucasus">North Caucasus</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Idel-Ural" title="Idel-Ural">Volga-Ural region</a>). Other religions, including Judaism, <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Buddhism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Buddhism (page does not exist)">Buddhism</a> are minority religions (though Tibetan Buddhism is the majority religion of Russia's <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Kalmykia" title="Republic of Kalmykia" class="mw-redirect">Republic of Kalmykia</a>). The 20th century saw the revival of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Neopaganism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Neopaganism (page does not exist)">Neopaganism</a> through movements such as <a href="/wiki/Wicca" title="Wicca">Wicca</a> and <a href="/wiki/Druidry" title="Druidry" class="mw-redirect">Druidry</a>.
</p><p>Europe has become a relatively <a href="/w/index.php?title=Secular&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Secular (page does not exist)">secular</a> continent, with an increasing number and proportion of <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">irreligious</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Atheism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Atheism (page does not exist)">atheist</a> and <a href="/wiki/Agnosticism" title="Agnosticism">agnostic</a> people, actually the largest<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Clarify&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Clarify (page does not exist)">Template:Clarify</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Western_religion" title="Western religion">Western world</a>. There are a particularly high number of self-described non-religious people in the Czech Republic, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Estonia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Estonia (page does not exist)">Estonia</a>, Sweden, Germany (East), and France.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pierre-Auguste_Renoir,_Le_Moulin_de_la_Galette.jpg" title="File:Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Le Moulin de la Galette.jpg">File:Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Le Moulin de la Galette.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i><a href="/wiki/Bal_du_moulin_de_la_Galette" title="Bal du moulin de la Galette">Dance at Le Moulin de la Galette</a></i>, 1876, by Pierre-Auguste Renoir</div></div></div>
<p>The culture of Europe can be described as a series of overlapping cultures; cultural mixes exist across the continent. There are cultural <a href="/wiki/Innovation" title="Innovation">innovations</a> and movements, sometimes at odds with each other. Thus the question of "common culture" or "common values" is complex.
</p><p>The foundation of European culture was laid by the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greeks</a>, strengthened by the <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_ancient_Rome" title="Culture of ancient Rome">Romans</a>, stabilised by <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, reformed by the 15th-century <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> and <a href="/wiki/Protestant_Reformation" title="Protestant Reformation">Reformation</a>, modernised by the 18th century <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a> and globalised by successive European empires between the 16th and 20th centuries.
{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>According to historian <a href="/wiki/Hilaire_Belloc" title="Hilaire Belloc">Hilaire Belloc</a>, for several centuries the peoples of Europe based their self-identification on the remaining traces of the <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_ancient_Rome" title="Culture of ancient Rome">Roman culture</a> and on the concept of <a href="/wiki/Christendom" title="Christendom">Christendom</a>, because many European-wide military alliances were of religious nature: the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Crusades&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Crusades (page does not exist)">Crusades</a> (1095–1291), the <a href="/wiki/Reconquista" title="Reconquista">Reconquista</a> (711-1492), the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Lepanto" title="Battle of Lepanto">Battle of Lepanto</a> (1571).<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>

</li>
</ul>
